Title: Journal 1595-1600
Bibliographical reference: Platter, Thomas the Younger. Beschreibung der Reisen durch Frankreich, Spanien, England und die Niederlande 1595-1600. Ed. Rut Keiser im Auftrag der historischen und antiquarischen Gesellschaft zu Basel. Basel: Schwabe, 1968.
Text: [In 1599, Platter witnessed a performance of] Julius Caesar [in London].
Comment: Son of the humanist Thomas Platter the Elder, studied medicine in Montpellier, later travelled to France, Spain, Flanders, and England. Witnessed a performance of Julius Caesar in London in 1599.

Title: Tagebuch seiner Reise zur Synode von Dordrecht (Ryhiner)
Bibliographical reference: Ryhiner, Emanuel. Tagebuch seiner Reise zur Synode von Dordrecht durch Holland, England und Frankreich. UB Basel.
Text: Tagebuch seiner Reise zur Synode von Dordrecht durch Holland, England und Frankreich (in Reisebeschreibungen UB).
Comment:
Gauss, Karl. Basilea Reformata: Die Gemeinden der Kriche Basel Stadt und Land und ihre Pfarrer seit der Reformation bis zur Gegenwart. Verlag der historischen und antiquarischen Gesellschaft, Universitätsbibliothek Basel, 1930. 133.
geb. 1695, Sohn des Benedikt und der Socin Dorothea. Gattin: Zäslin Anna Maria. 1715 SMC; 1715 bis 1721 Pfarrer am Waisenhaus; unternimmt eine Reise nach Frankreich und England; wird Feldprediger im fran- zösischen Dömmelschen Schweizerregiment; in Basel durch einen Vikar vertreten; 1721-1722 gemeiner Helfer; 1722 bis 1737 Pfarrer zu St. Alban; 1737-1755 Pfarer zu St. Leonhard; 1755-1759 Privatgelehrter; 1759-1764 Professor der Theologie. Gest. 19. VII. 1764.

Title: Little Book of My Whole Life
Bibliographical reference: Güntzer, Augustin. Kleines Büchelin vonmeinem ganzen Leben. fol. 111 recto or Brändle edition 2002, 192, my translation). Basel, UB, UBH H V 165. e-manuscripta. 1 Band (ca. 255 Blätter); 8' Abteilung H V; 165
Text: Since no German pewterer would be fed here, I went for walks here [in London] for 12 days, views the city for twelve days. Including the royal burial place [Westminster Abbey], the old castle [the Tower], the new Parliament House [which is] the vault where England should have been betrayed. [I then travelled] through the bishopric of Canterbury [by land to Dover, thence by boat to Dieppe].
Comment:
A poor migrating "Kannengiesser" in trouble for his religious convictions most of his life. Born in Alsace. His cousin Sebastian settled in basel and got very rich, father-in-law of JJ Frey's wife. Augustin arrived in Newcastle in 1620 from Helsingör, storms, earning his passage as an improvised cook, by ship continues to Cromer, Orford and finally London.
Weber, Alfred R. "Sebastian Güntzer: Ein Elsässer Würzkrämer in Basel." Basler Zeitschrift für Geschichte und Altertumskunde 94 (1995): 109-161.
Mieg, Philippe. "Les tribulations d'Augustin Guntzer." Annuaire de la soc. hist. et litt. de Colmar ; 8 (1958), S.48-65
Brändle, Fabian. "Nach oben und nach unten: Zwei Elsässer Vettern im Basel des 17. Jahrhunderts." Basler Zeitschrift für Geschichte und Altertumskunde 111 (2011): 23-44.
Line reference: @100162 Kleines Büchlein von meinem ganzen Leben
Subject: History, (auto-)biography

Title: Entry 45 in Johann Jacob Frey's Liber Amicorum 2 July 1625
Bibliographical reference: Translation Regula Hohl trillini, Annotation Alessandro Lattanzi.

Nomen JESUS in ore mel est, in Aure melos, in core jubilus. Bernh[ard].
Doctissimo juveni - viro Doct. Johann Jacob frey bexe ? volentiae testificandae causa [...] Johannes Wollaebius
Ecclesiae Basiliensis pastor veterisque testamentis Professor
2 Julii 1626

Translation
The name JESUS is honey in the mouth, melody in the ear, joy in the heart. Bernh[ard].
For the most learned youth - man Dr. Johann Jacob Frey ??[...] Johann Wolleb
Pastor of the Church of Basel and Professor for Old Testament
2 July 1626
Comment:
The quotation is from Bernhard of Clairvaux's Sermones in Cantica canticorum XV, 6 (Patrologia Latina, vol. CLXXXIII, col. 847).

Title: Entry 53 in Frey's Liber Amicorum August 1625
Bibliographical reference: Wasserhun, Reinhard. "[Entry 53 in Frey's Liber Amicorum August 1625]." Stammbuch von Johann Jacob Frey. University Library of Basel UBH Frey-Gryn Mscr V 19. Fol. 53 [normalized spelling].
Text:
Ut salutaria quaedam, quae citra gustum tactumque odore proficiunt, ita virtus utilitatem etiam ex longinquo et latens fundit. Sive spatiatur et se utitur suo iure, sive precarios habet excessus cogiturque vela contrahere, sive otiosa mutaque est et in angusto circumsaepta, sive adaperta, in quocumque habitu est, prodest.

 Reinhard Wasserhun [...]
Basilea ad patria m[ense] Augusto
1625

Translation
As there are certain salutary things that without our tasting and touching them benefit us by their mere odour, so virtue sheds her advantage even from a distance, and in hiding. Whether she walks abroad and of her own right makes herself active, or has her appearances on sufferance and is forced to draw in her sails, or is inactive and mute and pent within narrow bounds, or is openly displayed, no matter what her condition is, she always does good

Reinhard Wasserhun [...]
Basel, my home town, in the month of August 1625
Comment:
A passage from Seneca's "On Tranquillity of mind". The translation given here is fromMoral Essays, Volume II: De Consolatione ad Marciam. De Vita Beata. De Otio. De Tranquillitate Animi. De Brevitate Vitae. De Consolatione ad Polybium. De Consolatione ad Helviam. Trans. John W. Basore. Loeb Classical Library 254. Cambridge (MA): Harvard University Press, 1932. 231.
SECONDARY Vischer, Christoph. "Die Stammbücher der Universitätsbibliothek Basel: ein beschreibendes Verzeichnis von Christoph Vischer." Festschrift Karl Schwarber. Basel: Schwabe, 1949. 247-264.
Line reference: @100103 Entry 53 in Frey's Liber Amicorum August 1625
Modifications: NaHu#007056 Johann Jacob Frey II / WoPa#006320 Ut salutaria quaedam

Title: Entry 47 in Johann Jacob Frey's Liber Amicorum 4 August 1625
Bibliographical reference: Transcription and translation Renate Würsch (Hebrew) and Regula Hohl Trillini.
Text:
באלוהים ישעי
Christus in officio mediatorio neque collegam neque Vicarium habet ullum.
Little said, soon amended. [...].

Translation
In God is my salvation.
In his office as mediator, Christ has no equal and no substitute
Little said, soon amended. [...].
Comment:
The Hebrew passage may echo Habakkuk 3:18 or Psalm 62:8. The English passage alludes to Wolfgang Meyer's studies in England and to young Johann Jacob Frey's imminent departure for France and England.
SECONDARY Vischer, Christoph. "Die Stammbücher der Universitätsbibliothek Basel: ein beschreibendes Verzeichnis von Christoph Vischer." Festschrift Karl Schwarber. Basel: Schwabe, 1949. 247-264.

Title: Entry 56 in Johann Jacob Frey's Liber Amicorum 6 May 1626
Bibliographical reference: entry
Text:
Aletheuein ei agape
הבל הבלים
eruditione ac pietate ornatissimo juveni D. Jacobo Frey amoris monumentum adscribebam
Benedictus Turrettinus
VI Maj 1626

Translation
Telling truth is love
The Lord is my light and my salvation [Ecclesiastes 1:2]
To the young Dr. Johann Jacob Frey, shining in piety and erudition, I have written this as a memento of affection.
Benedict Turrettini
6 May 1626
Comment: Johann Jacob Frey studied with Turrettini in Geneva from 1625 to 1627. This album entry was most probably wriiten in Geneva.

Title: Entry 147 in Johann Jacob Frey's Liber Amicorum 27 July 1627
Bibliographical reference: entry.
Text: tbe
Comment:
Schlueter 2015, 676: "Wotton may or may not have known Frey prior to his visit (he certainly knew the Earl of Cork and may have been instrumental in arranging Frey's appointment). Whatever their relationship, when Eton's Provost signed Frey's album, he exhibited a bit of intellectual bravado: rather than inscribing the month and day of his entry, he provided as-tronomical coordinates, anticipating a solar eclipse that was to take place on 1 August (Jul-ian). This was not an eclipse he would personally have seen, it being visible only in northern polar climes, nor would he have known that this was the shortest partial hybrid solar eclipse of the century. But a solar eclipse would, indeed, have commanded the interest of this pol-yhistor, as had his meeting with Johannes Kepler in 1620,36 his viewing of the comet of 1618,37 and, no doubt, the publication that year (1627) of Kepler's Rudolphine Tables (based on his version of the Copernican solar system)."
SECONDARY Schlueter, June and Markus Dubischar. "Traces of Henry Wotton in continental Alba Amicorum." Renaissance Studies 30:5 (2015): 666-683.
Vischer, Christoph. "Die Stammbücher der Universitätsbibliothek Basel: ein beschreibendes Verzeichnis von Christoph Vischer." Festschrift Karl Schwarber. Basel: Schwabe, 1949. 247-264.
Line reference: @100137 Entry 147 in Frey's Liber Amicorum

Title: Letter to Zurich or Switzerland 31 October 1629
Bibliographical reference: Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini. Probably STAB?
Text:
To be translated
Amplissimi Spectatissimus Domini
Quantum me iuvierit viderer Civitatem vestram are salubrem. Pibus florentem, eruditione claram, virtute civitum munitam, Ecllesiare simul nutricem & almsunma nequicquam coner exprimere. Neg sane snimus ets soluta beneficia atq. Splendidissimam. Amicissimam receptionem. Qua Ms m Servi ? Regis mei gratiam honorastist nudis. (licet dignissimis) & audibus pensare; Equidem Matri ? eius uam diu ommnia seculo narravi atq. Magnas vobis eo nimine habet, gratias & aget, ubicumque se dederit occasio quod testatura Agentem (mi Helvetia commoraturi?) ad vos mittit Oliverium Flemming, virum inter bonos & idoneos meiorsi notae & Mati? Suae probitate " diligentia gratum; denig? Qualem decetr mitti ad cordatos & sapientes. Ille vobis expont, quam Rex vobis bene velit. Quod ad me, vors rogatos velimn, ut ad vestra me me benefacta addatis unum, datis sicilicet occasionem,. Qua vestris commodis inserviam, & iuare possim Rempublicam vestro regimine Falicem?: Eam Deus O. M. semper foveat, & augeat, ex anime precor. Spectatis ?? amantissimus Carlile
Comment: SECONDARY: The First Carlisle Sir James Hay, First Earl of Carlisle as Courtier, Diplomat and Entrepreneur, 1580-1636 Author(s): Roy E. Schreiber Source: Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 74: 7 (1984): 1-202.

Title: Entry 05 in Frey's Liber Amicorum February 1630
Bibliographical reference: Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan, Richard. "[Entry 05 in Liber Amicorum February 1630]." Stammbuch von Johann Jacob Frey. University Library of Basel UBH Frey-Gryn Mscr V 19. Fol. 5 [normalized spelling]. TRanscription and translation Regula Hohl Trillini
Text:
Sinceré et constanter.
Richardus Vicecomes Dungarvianae fideli hactenus ? ephoro, nunc sacellano suo dilectissimo Magistro Johannes Jacobo Frey Basiliensi in perpetuam sui memoriam haec adscripsit Oxoniae in Collegio Aed. Christi Anno 1630 mense Februario.

Translation
Sincerely and constantly.
Richard Viscount Dungarvan here writes to his former faithful tutor, now his chaplain, his most beloved Master Johann Jacob Frey of Basel, in eternal memory. Oxford, Christ Church College, in the year 1630, in the month of February.
Comment: SECONDARY Vischer, Christoph. "Die Stammbücher der Universitätsbibliothek Basel: ein beschreibendes Verzeichnis von Christoph Vischer." Festschrift Karl Schwarber. Basel: Schwabe, 1949. 247-264.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 5 March or 1630 or 1631 (ENGLISH)
Bibliographical reference: Ub Basel Frey-Grynaeum I 12, fol. 135. Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized. Dungarvan to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1631-03-05 Place: Dublin
Text:
Worthy Tutor,
I think it needless for me to write now much of? the affection I bear you or desire I have of your speedy and by me much desired return hither, I presume in these you are well satisfied of me, as also of my further unbendments (?) towards you, when ability shall better serve. Then (?) yet it hath to let you know I will not be wanting in a meet contribution for all your pains and love either past or future. My father hath now also writ unto you touching your speedy return to us I hope it will be yours and your friends' satisfaction that it may be […] let me add this much and assure you faithfully that wherein his/he? comes short of your fair expectation or merit I will God willing supply to your full contentment and therefore doubt me not, but venture to return with all expedition unto
Your most faithful friend and Pupil
Dungarvan
Dublin this 5 March 1630
My father gave me leave to go into France this spring, I only stay for your return to go with me therefore I pray make all haste you can
Comment: There is also a German version of this text
Line reference: @100002 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 5 March 1631
Modifications: NaHu#007080 Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork
URL:
Meinem recht würdigen Freund Herrn Jakob Frey, freien Künsten Magister.
Tutor, ich halte es für überflüssig, viel davon zu [...], wie gross meine Affection gegen Euch [...]
gehorsamen Freund und pupillo
Dublin den 5. März 1631
Mein Vater hat mir erlaubt, diesen Frühling in Frankreich zu reisen [...] allein [...] Eure Ankunft, damit wir miteinander dahin reisen mögen

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 17 April 1630
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth CM 17, fol. 8. published in Lismore Papers Vol. 3, 1888, pp. 157-158 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini from Lismore Papers Dungarvan to Cork Date: 1630-04-17 Place: London
Text: tbe
Comment:
Summary from the Chatsworth Catalogue:
The desire of Lord Goring and his sister to sue him, has withdrawn him from his studies at Oxford for a fortnight, having the full consent of Dr Pierce. There died of the sickness here 11 last week; it is at Cambridge, Greenwich and other places. Begs leave to come to Ireland for a month or two this summer. Had to wait for his last quarteridge 6 weeks, and Dr Pierce, for all his promises, refused to lend him £8. Lord Digby safely landed at Chester.

Title: Resolves
Bibliographical reference: Feltham, Owen. Resolves: A duple century. 4th ed. 1631 London: Seile. Basel, UB, UBH Frey-Gryn O VI 5
Text: The copy of this book held in the Library of the University of Basel carries the exlibris of Johann Jacob Frey but seems otherwise pristine. It is bound in heavy leather with a ridged back and gilt edges.
Comment:
Owen Feltham (1602 – February 23, 1668) was an English writer, author of a book entitled Resolves, Divine, Moral, and Political (c. 1620), containing 146 short essays. It had great popularity in its day. Feltham was for a time in the household of the Earl of Thomond as chaplain or sec., and published (1652), Brief Character of the Low Countries. His most cited essay is "How the Distempers of these Times should affect wise Men" which was selected for inclusion in John Gross' The Oxford Book of Essays, a compilation of over a hundred of the finest essays in the English language.
Resolves, Divine, Moral and Political

Feltham was still a teenager when he published his first edition of Resolves in 1623. This collection of essays played a crucial role in the development of the English essay as a genre.

The original edition included 100 “resolves” that were considered to be “short, aphoristic commentaries on aspects of the three realms delineated by the title: divine, ethical, and political…[and] they concern[ed] in equal measure the private and public realms of middle-class English life.” Later revisions reflect how Feltham attempted to amalgamate these three distinct dimensions of “middle-class English life”—divine, ethical and political—into a more cohesive context. Or, in other words, the revisions reflect “ ‘the expansion of aphorisms into statements that approach conversation’…[which] corresponds to a more tolerant humanism.” This tolerance is perhaps best demonstrated in regards to the ubiquitous Woman Question, a debate which continued to play a large role in the social atmosphere of Renaissance Britain. Both men and women joined in the debate, and though most men viewed the fairer sex in rigid terms—as either “unconstant” or “excellent”—there were many men like Feltham who preferred to “[accept] some assumptions about gender but [question] many others: he asks commonsense questions and is willing to look beyond stereotypes.” In his 1661 edition of Resolves, Feltham’s 85th resolve, entitled "Of Marriage and Single Life," he writes: "A wise wife comprehends both sexes: she is a woman for her body, and she is a man within: for her soul is like her Husbands.... It is a Crown of blessings, when in one woman a man findeth both a wife and a friend." In his 1628 edition, which includes the resolve entitled “Of Woman,” Feltham observes the social disparities of his time in regards to gender equality. Though he does not offer any solutions, his commentary could be considered a type of proto-feminist or proto-egalitarianist philosophy: “Whence proceed the most abhorred villainies, but from a masculine unblushing impudence? When a woman grows bold and daring, we dislike her, and say, ‘she is too like a man’: yet in our selves, we magnify what we condemn. Is not this injustice?”
Line reference: @100424 Resolves
Modifications: WoPa@007971 Book owned by JJ Frey

Title: Letter to the Magistrate of Basel 19/29 December 1631
Bibliographical reference: Staatsarchiv Basel D1 and FG 12 23, fol. 154 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Cork to the magistrate of Basel Date: 1631-12-19 Place: Dublin Castle
Text:
Right honourable ? my good Lords and friends I have thought fit and necessary to acquaint your Lordship's honour rgar ... especially ... by one of the members of your Commonwealth Mr James Frey master of Arts (whose former pains and success in the education of my oldest Son and Heir Richard Lord Viscount of Dungarvan hath sufficiently ciommended him to me for his trustaycare and abilities. I have made choice of him as one of my Chaplains to wait on me here at Dublin the principal City f thi Kingdom of Irland and seat of the State. And [...] all to have the care and inspection ? over my dearly beloved Son until such time as I should think fit to send him abroad to travel for his better experience and knowledge. To which end I did send and unto him many of my [...] at and several eims entreating him that in deard of the manifold good that would thereby redound both to my son and hilsefge he would accept of my favourable offers and pleasure and return thence again unto me, wherein I omitted no argumants that might persuade and draw him to this my former [...] whereupon he receaving my lettes and acknowledging both my [...] and the common good that should arise by his care and industry to the whole state of this church and kingdom, was pleased to reparie highter tio this Court and afterwards upon submission expectation of our Lordship's [...] received the charge of my Chaplain and Tutor to my eldest son, where at the same time I conferred upon him a dignity of the church. But since having received letters ? from home, (whereby he is charged and commanded to return), he came to me with a relation of such engagements as he ought to his Chruch and to his mother country and friends and thereupon askyed my leave for this return, this which though I cannot [...] yet would I not suffer him presently to undertake his journey in this time of year when both sea and land prove dangerous. Considering also with myself the Latin proverb Dies Diem Docit that in the meantime his mother and friends at home would think and judge better of this my [...] I resloved to make this my intent known to the lords and theregore wished hm to write to his friend [...] and send this my letter (as it is directed) to you wherein I do firendly and seriously entreat you Lords [...] in reagred of the common faith we all embcare in regard of the good that will redound to me and the churcih in [...] of friendship and corresponodnce which I seek hereby between you and me,, and lastly in regard of Mr Frey's own preferment and honour you will be pleased (if not to leave him to me altogether yrz to give him leave to stay wwith me a year or two until my son (Whom I intend God willing) to send abroead next spring having finished his travel and [...] settled at hioem which I will estomate a [...] done to me, and in encouragement of further friendship which whereof as I expect this grant as a beginning from you; so [...] may be assured of a true continuation on my part upon all poccasions that may be ministered to do service to you Lords and that State. This commengin you Lords together with the happiness [...] state of your Church and commonwealth to God's gracious protection
Your Lordship's very loving friend

[...] His majesty's Castle at Dublin the 19th of December 1631

[Address on the envelope:] To the right Honorable, the Magistrate of the City and territories of Basel, one of the thirteen Cantons of the famous commonwealth of the Switzers, my very good Lords and friends.
Comment: There is also a German version of this text.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 7 October 1631
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 62-63 Microfilm pdf p. 81-82 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini; spelling normalized Ro[bert] Robotham to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1631-10-07 Place: London
Text: Worthy Sir We came out of Ireland some month since where we left all well, as passed some 3 months’ time away there, up and down, sometimes in [?] the trophies of my Lord of Cork's fortune, sometimes in visiting friends. My lordship no doubt hath given you an account of his negotiation with my Lord Deputy on my Lord Cork’s behalf, whom my Lord found too wilful and confident of his integrity and full of [?] towards the Deputy that nothing almost could be effected, yet my Lord Deputy did in a manner chalk a way out that he was to go in to compass a fair accommodation of the business and hinder it from coming to a public hearing, thereupon lies were sent whilst we were there to my Lord Chamberlin and my Lord Salisbury to move the King in it, but he would do nothing in it till any Lord Deputy certified the state of the cause, that I [?] nothing, will satisfy my Lord of Cork but a total taking up of all things and the part with nothing which cannot be done! To this present Mr. Badnedge is come over with Franck and Robin[there seems to be a heart as the dot of the “i”] to Eaton; but his chief business I believe is to see if he can labour some about the King for a prohibition to the Deputy to stay proceeding which he will I doubt never obtain and my Lord hath often told him the Deputy must do the Act when he had done all he could, we shall see this term the Events, Nothing[?] standing his confidence of the cause, my [?] Radcliff offered upon his credit to make it appear that he would [?] of his own [?], and no proofs at all, and was not nice to my Lord of Cork so [in margin] much this business hath grieved and troubled my Lord extremely for that he finds my Lord Dungarvan infinite[?] passionate, and zealous on his father’s behalf; not with all the [?] as some suppose: This enclosed was sent after me 2 days when my Lord [Crec?] was shut up, and he commanded me to send you it, but since I came to London I hear that my Lord Deputy hath given you nothing[?] thereof, and sent for you back; however you will see [next page] my Lord’s care and desire of your return to the good[?] purpose; the King and Queen are back out of town and here is no news at all that I hear since I came only new levies throughout England towards the setting out of a very great Fleet next year, the Queen is with child, for certain and so I hope is my lady Dungarvan we expected her coming back with us but she will be at Dublin this Winter, Mrs Clifton came with us and Johnickby[?], by this is married and so was her maid Ann Franklin before we came from Lismore to Mr. Thomas Pomfret but the greatest news of all is that little Ms. Hr. Clifford came run[?] a love; I am come to carry my lady down and am the unwelcomest[?] man in the world I cannot help it Pardon (?) I beseech this hasty scribbling, and believe I am most assuredly your affectionate and most humble servant Robert Robotham London 7 October 1630
Line reference: @100011 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 7 October 1631

Title: Letter to Henry Clifford 6 August 1632
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth CM 17, fol. 110, published in Lismore papers Lismore Vol. 3, 1888, p. 188-190 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, normalized spelling Dungarvan to Lord Clifford Date: 1632-08-06
Text: [Protests he never made any slighting remarks of Mrs Clifford, or said he never saw woman he liked worse. On the contrary he has always been her humble servant, since he first saw her. Disclaims the idea that they merely meant to keep the match afoot, till his father had wrought his ends with the Lord Deputy, and begs him tell Lord Salisbury so. Is not answerable for what Lord Goring may say. For himself, all he has ever said, was that he was under contract, and that he did not mean to marry until his return from travel. Assures Lord Clifford however of his honorable intentions].
Line reference: @100040 Letter to Henry Clifford 6 August 1632

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 16 July 1632
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth CM 17, fol. 106, published in Lismore Papers Vol. 3, 1888, pp.184-187. Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini Dungarvan to Cork Date: 1632-07-16 Place: London
Text: [Related his proceedings at York in his last letter. Arrived here on the 8th, and on the 10th, waited on the King at St James's and desired the Lord of Holland to bring him to kiss the King's hand and he immediately went down into chapel, where the King sat to have his picture drawn, and brought him up. The King told him he had written a letter to the Earl, propounding a match between Lady Ann Fielding and his son, to which he had received an answer. Replied that he was now sent to attend His Majesty's will and pleasure, with which the King seemed very well satisfied and enquired if there was any engagement between Mrs Clifford and him. Replied that he had veiwed the lady and liked her well, but was free from all engagement. The King said he did not wish to urge his affection, but desired he would match with a family which above all he esteemed and loved. Replied that an engagement between himself and Mrs Ann Villiers had been broken off 7 years ago, and that he had made a vow not to match into that family. Then the King said: "My Lord, conclude upon nothing suddenly, lay your hand upon your heart, and give me an answer as your affection move you; this much I will assure your, that whether you like or dislike the lady I will never think the worse of you". Will attend the King at Otelands, and there give him his answer, and desire leave to travel.].
Line reference: @100042 Letter to the Earl of Cork 16 July 1632

Title: Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan 6 August 1632
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth CM 17, fol. 109 [Enclosed with CM/17/108], published in Lismore papers Lismore Vol. 3, 1888, p. 187-188 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini Henry Clifford, Earl of Cumberland to Dungarvan Date: 1632-08-06 Place: Hatfield
Text: [...] his daughter, [...].
Comment:
Summary from Chatsworth Catalogue
Thinks proper to acquaint him with a current report, that there was no serious intent in the marriage treaty, between his lordship and and that he had been heard to say, "he never saw woman whom he liked worse." Lord Salisbury, her uncle, says these words stick in his stomach, and holds it most requisite his lordship should be freed of the aspersion, before he went on his travel.

Line reference: @100041 Letter to Louis de Dieu 9 June 1632
Modifications: NaHu#007055 Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan / NaHu#007056 Johann Jacob Frey II
URL:
Salutem, à salutis fonte D. N. Iesu Christo.
Libros, quos ad te et Clarissimum Vossium miseram acceptos fuisse, laetus ab utroque vestrûm audio: sed literas, alteri cuidam è Belgio vestro (in Hispaniam, ut audivi, postea profecto) commissas, interiisse video. Quae jactura effecit, ut nulli facile nuncio fidem deferendarum literarum adhibuerim hactenus. Discedente vero hinc ad vos nobilissimo Juvene Dunharvainae Vicecomite; oblatam tam opportunè occasionem praetermittere nolens, perspectae nobis fidei [Greek phrase] ipsius Vicecomitis Ephoro, tradendas curo quas jam scribo literas. Atque ut [Greek phrase] quod aiunt, ab eo in quo postremas tuas terminaveras, ego nunc incipiam: monachum illum, de quo ad Dominum Rivetum scripsit Marinus Marsenius, non alium quàm Johannem Morinum fuisse suspicor, qui tum in prolixâ illâ praefatione editioni [Greek phrase] (quae Lutetiae Anno 1628 Graeco-latina prodiit) praefixa, tum in Exercitationibus Ecclesiasticis (quas in Samaritanum Pentateuchum ibidem Anno 1631. evulgavit) ex Graecorum et Samariticorum codicum fide, Hebraeum nostrum textum corruptum et depravatum esse, stultissimâ operâ astruere conatus est. Stultissimam enim quid ni dixerim cum eâdem ipse operâ sua sibi caedat vineta, et (quod probè est à te annimadversum) Vulgatae editionis Latinae authoritatem pariter enervet: Tridentinorum suorum Decreti parùm memor, qui ut haec ipsa editio pro authenticâ habeatur statuerunt,et ut eam nemo rejicere quovis praetextu audeat vel praesumat; atque adeò eodem cum illo afflatus spiritu, cui immanis iste versus olim excidit. [462] Pereant amici, dum unà inimici intercidant. Tui et eruditissimi Constantini tui erit, hominis nimio sibi placentis audaciam atque [Greek phrase] comprimere, et sacrorum fontium integritatem sartam tectam ab omni detrimento conservare. Quâ in re praestandâ, maximo vobis erit subsidjo Veteris Testamenti Editio Syriaca, quam ab Apostolorum temporibus hucusque magno omnium Orientis populorum, qui Chaldaicâ sive Syriacâ utuntur linguâ, consensu retentam, et semper summâ in veneratione et auctoritate esse habitam; et demum publice in omnibus eorum Ecclesijs antiquissimis constitutis in Syriâ, Mesopotamiâ, Chaldaeâ, Aegypto, et denique in universi Orientis partibus dispersis ac disseminatis, lectam esse ac legi, in Diatribâ de Chaldaicae lingua Utilitate confirmat Georgius Amira Syrus. Cum enim haec in Ecclesiâ Antiochenâ (à quà Christianum nobis processit nomen) à primis usque temporibus recepta, et a veteribus Patribus (Melitone Sardens. Basilio Caesareens. Apollinario Laodiceno, Eusebio Emeseno, Diodoro Tarsensi, Theodoreto Cyrensi, Procopio Gazaeo, Hesychio, Polychronio, et authore Questionum & Respons. ad Orthodoxos quae Justino Martyri tribuuntur) subinde citata fuerit: argumentum nobis praebet [Greek phrase], loca textus Hebraici cum ea consentientia à posterioribus, Masorethis et Judaeorum Rabbinis (quod isti nugatores clamitant) haudquaquam interpolari potuisse. Quare, sicut anteà Samaritanum, ita nunc Syriacum Pentateuchum per D. Freyum nostrum tibi mittendum duxi: ut ad Mosaicos quamprimùm libros ab ardelionis istius nefariâ Criticâ vindicandos aggredereris. Habeo et totius Veteris instrumenti librorum (quam mihi emptam in Syriâ vidit D. Jacobus Golius) versionem similem, nec Canonicorum tantum sed Apocryphorum quoque adjuncto etiam Flavii Josephi de Macchabaeis. Hanc,et quicquid penès me est Samariticorum fragmentorum, tecum communicaturus sum libens: si quando animum induxeris Parisiensem (quam expectamus) Samaritani et Syriaci contextus editionem cum MSS. nostris exemplaribus comparare. Id enim tantum relinquitur peragendum; primae editionis gloriâ, quam Academiae vestrae optabam, aliorum festinatione jam praereptâ. Neque alium in finem quaternio ille Arabico-Samaritanus, elegantissimo Charactere exaratus, à me missus fuerat, quam ut formulae archetypae, quas matrices vocant, inde exprimerentur si, quod sperabam, Editio ista apud vos procederet. Integrum verò Samaritanum Pentateuchum in Arabicam et Cuthaeis vernaculum linguam translatum extat: licet ea solum pars, quae Genesin et Deuteronomion complectitur, ad meas manus pervenerit. Sunt etiam apud me nummi fex aenei vetustissimi, partim Phoeniciis partim Arabicis literarum notis (longe ante tempora Mahummedica) insigniti: quorum usus fortasse aliquis in dissertatione de Samaritanorum Characterum origine esse poterit. Arabici Psalterii tria habui exemplaria, satis antiqua: quorum unum D. Londinensi Episcopo, Academiae Oxoniensis dignissimo Cancellario, cum aliquam multis aliis codicibus MSS. nuper à me donatum est: alterum quod D. Gulielmo Bedwello commodaveram, eo jam vitâ functo, vix est ut recuperari a me posse sperem: Bibliotheca mea tertium adhuc conservat. Habeo & Genefim Arabicè ex Graeco versam, & amplo commentario explicatam: Arabicas quo{que} Homilias in Sacrae Historiae partem, à Josepho incipientes. Eâdem linguâ Chrysostomi Conciones Quadragesimales habeo, quae in nostris desiderantur libris, & Graecis & Latinis. Arabicum quo{que} Nomocanomen possideo; in quo veterum Synodorum Canones ad certos titulos reducti continentur. [463] E. Syriacis Ephraemi, praeter tractatum quem habes de amore Sapientiae, Hymni apud me sunt de Humilitate, Rescipiscentiâ, Fine seculi, Gog & Magog, Monachis & Eremitis; Nocturnae meditatio contra ebrietatem & crapulam: & Praecationum liber. Item Hymni varii Alphabetici. Habeo & Syriacum in quatuor Evangelia Commentarium: & in universa ferè Biblia alterum Thesauri Secretorum titulo praenotatum: cui & quatuor Tabulae Chronologieae sunt insertae. • 1. Patriarcharum, ab Adamo ad Mosem. • 2. Judicum, à Josuâ ad Samuelem. • 3. Regum à Saule ad Sedechiam. • 4. Imperatorum exterorum à Nebuchadnetsare ad Vespatianum us{que} Librum Sermonum in dies festos his addas licet: et Syriacam Grammaticam absolutissimam. Samaritica verò scripta, praeter Pentateuchum, quae nactus sum omnia ad communem amicum nostrum D. Johannem Seldenum transmisi: à quo, quod contineant poteris rescisere: et de nostris quidem hactenùs. Accepi, simul cum Canonicarum Epistolarum Editione Syrà, eruditissimas tuas in quatuor Evangelia Animadversiones: in quibus quod culpem nihil est, si prosusam mei (nihil tale promeriti) laudationem exceperis. Omnino luculentum opus est, et reconditâ multiplici{que} doctrinâ refertum: nec, si me audias, prius conquiesces quam pari diligentiâ et simili Commentationis genere quod Novi Testamenti est reliquum illustraveris. Nihil enim certe in morte olarissimi Amanae amisisse nos video, quod non Academia vestra Lugdunensis in Te, in Imperatore, in Golio, abunde compenset. Reliquit vero filium post se doctissimus Buxtorffius, qui Parentis vestigiis et loco insistens, magnam de se apud omnes spem eoncitat, inprimis sacrarum literarum studiosos: dum, quod audio, Rabbinicum studium sacris aliquando meditationibus concionando temperat. Vidi et ego specimen Concordantiarum Patris, quas pro merito magni facio; majori tamen desiderio expecto Lexicon, de quo filius ad Clariss. Heinssum: quandoquidem (quod à Buxtorffio P. verissime est notatum) id quod dederunt nobis Parisienses, bono publico parum consulat. Loco tuorum remitto munera [Greek phrase] plane [Greek phrase]: Praedestinatianae (quae Ecclesias vestras tantopere perturbat) Controversiae Historiam, et Veterum Epistolarum Hibernicarum sarraginem: utram{que} manu meâ correctam, ut si deinceps fortè edantur, ex isto [Greek phrase] paulo prodire possint emendatiores. Tu donum ipsum non spectabis, quod est profecto leviculum, sed animum summè erga te affectum donantis, qui est
Totus tuus, Jacobus Usserus Armacanus.
Dublinii, V. Idus Junias, 1632.
S. D. Casauboni apud vos edendae sint Epistolae; habeo illius aliquot, quas Typographo impertiam.

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 19 January 1632
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth Devonshire Collection CM 17, fol. 130 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Dungarvan to Cork Date: 1632-01-19 Place: Paris
Text:
My most honoured Lord and Father,
If my letters do not come so speedily into your Lordship’s hands as you do desire, I beseech your Lordship to believe it is neither Mr Frey's nor my neglect, which we lose no opportunity […].
your former letter to Burlamachi [...]
I was advised by Mr Frey to make use of his letter of credit

Text:
My most honoured Lord Father,
At my arrival in Paris I writ unto your Lordship […].
I beseech your lordship to take order for some letters of credit as your lordship shall think fit upon the account Mr. Frey sends you over and will assure you that nothing shall be spent but what shall be for your honour and my profit.

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 25 September 1632
Text: [Summary from the Chatsworth archive] Has taken lodgings in Paris for the winter, and has arranged his exercises thus. From 7 to 9 rides the great horse; 9 to 11 learns to dance; after dinner from 1 to 3 learns to fence; from 3 to 6 studies logic and mathematics. Hears it is reported he is the father of his sister Kildare's nurses child. Vows to God he is as free as the man who never saw her. [Leyden?]

Title: Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork 6 December 1632
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth House CM_17_124 Transcription Regula Hohl, spelling normalized Dungarvan to Cork Date: 1632-12-06
Text:
My most honoured Lord Father,
if my humble thanks could express those joys which your long-desired lines did beget within my heart, when I had the honour to receive them. I am confident that your lordship should find no less testimonies of my filial duty and obedience in my acknowledgments than I have had assurance in your lordship's kind letter of your fatherly care and affection. But since I have no other thanks but a real expression of conforming my endeavours to your lordship's command, I beseech you my lord to believe that it shall be ever the chiefest of my studies to follow all those wholesome instructions wherewith your lordship was pleased to honour me with in your letter. All my exercises I thank God daily follow without any intermission and have the greater desire to attain to some perfection in them every day [...] other at my studies I spend every day tow hours, one at the mathematics and the other at logic with Mr Frey, who is the carefullest governor and [?] manager of all things he undertakes that ever I knew. When I ahve any idle time I spend it in reading French histories or conversing with them from whom I can gain some knowledge of the affairs of France. Your lordship need to not fear me stirring out of my lodging late at night; the murders which are her almost every night committed are sufficient motives to keep me within doors after candlelitghts. I had before I received your last written to some of those noblemen your lordship made mention of. To the [...] I will not [...] to write very careful letters. I do almost wrote to Sir William Beecher every fortnight, and when there here happens anything worth the relating I will impart it to [...].
Lord Goring [...]
I have been advised by Mr. Frey to keep that of Mr. Burlamachi till I begin to remove from hence [...]
I beseech your lordship to condescend to allow me 1000 a year for by the particular which Mr. Frey sent you over your lordship may perceive that less will not serve my turn to live like your lordship's son. [...] I have done all I could to write a small hand like Mr Frey's. I hope this will please your lordship.
Line reference: @100064 Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork 6 December 1632
Modifications: NaHu#007056 Johann Jacob Frey II / NaHu#007020 William Beecher / NaHu#007936 Philip Burlamachi / NaHu#007971 George Lord Goring

Title: Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan 26 November 1632
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth Devonshire Collection CM 17, fol. 123 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Cork to Dungarvan Date: 1632-11-26 Place: Dublin
Text:
My dear son,
I have received but one letter from yourself and one from your tutor Mr Frey since your arrival at Paris […]. [Summary from Chatsworth archive: Cork has paid Mr Burlamachi £375 for his next half-year's allowance; is displeased to find that he has borrowed £200 from Lord Goring. Has given him tether enough and begs he will contain himself within reasonable limits. Begs him to give over his loose hand and to write a fine neat character like Mr Frey's]

Title: Letter to Valerius Heitzmann 16 February 1632
Bibliographical reference: UB Basel Frey-Grynaeum II 7, fol. 177. Transcription and translation Regula Hohl Trillini. Johann Jacob Frey to Valerius Heitzmann. Date: 1632-02-16 Place: Dublin
Text:
Sir,
as much as the messenger's haste permits, I assure you that I have not forgotten my patrons, of whom I have ever considered you one; having had so many testimonies of your favours that it would be impossible to doubt it and the most ingrate thing in the world not to acknowledge / recognize? them. In recognition of this [state of affairs], accept (I beg of you) to accept a summary of my decisions since time does not permit me to give you the particulars, which you (if it please you) will hear from Dr. Zwinger and Mr. Battier, my kinsman.
After my mother and Mr. Zwinger had heard through my letters that I had accepted a double situation which the Earl of Cork,, currently Viceroy of Ireland, had offered me so that I would serve him as chaplain and as the tutor of his eldest son, the Viscount Dungarvan for a time of two years with the will and consent of my superiors??, they charged me with such [...]
your very humble and obedient servant,
JJ Frey
Line reference: @100014 Letter to Valerius Heitzmann 16 February 1632
Modifications: NaHu#007055 Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan / NaHu#007080 Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork / NaHu#007083 Jacob Battier / NaHu#007084 Theodor Zwinger / NaHu@007903 Esther Frey-Ostein / NaHu#007917 Johann Caspar Bauhin
URL: Monsieur, Autant que la haste du messager me permet, je vous assure que je n'oublie point mes Patrons desquels je vous ay toujours tenu un; ayant eu tant de témoignages de vos faveurs, qu'il serait impossible d'en douter et la chose la plus ingrate du monde de non les reconnaître. En reconnaissance de cela, acceptez (je vous supplie) du sommarie de mes resolutions puisque le temps [ne] me permet pas de vous donner les particularités lesquelles (s'il vous plaît) vous entendrez (?) de M. Dr. Zwinger et Monsieur Battier mon cousin. Après que ma mère et Monsieur Zwinger avaient entendu par mes lettres que j'avais accepté d'une double condition que Monsieur le conte de Cork à présent viceroy d'Irlande m' avait offerte pour lui servie en chaplain et gouverneur de son fils ainé le Vicomte de Dungarvan l'espace de deux ans et au plaisir et volonté de mes supérieurs: ils m'ont chargé de telle indifertion (??) et timerité que sans savoir les raisons qui m'ont induit a entretenir cette vocation, le monde me penserait hors de jugement et tout à fait éloigné du devoir que je dois a Dieu, a ma patrie et a mes parents. Mais s'il vous plait de participer des protestations que j'ai fait et fais encore sur toutes? rémonstrances, vous verrez que mon intention se trouvera bonne, juste, pleine de profit et d'honneur et pur le bien de ce royaume et de notre Église. Outre les raisons particulières et celles que concernent ma personne, qui à la vérité m'ont donné occasion de songer aux conditions longtemps offertes,. Et encore, que j'eusse su répondre à toutes leurs objections (comme je fais pour autant qu'il touche ma conscience et salut) je n'ai coulu pourtant disputer avec ceux qui me pourront toujours commander: ainsi au contraire [je] me suis soumis a leur volonté pourvu qu'ils m'encouragent à mon retour; autrement je serais bien fol de quitter une bonne place et revenant? à Basle et perdre toute espérance selon qui les lettres que j'ai reçues de là, me semblait ???. En attendant leur réponse, j’espère qu’ils me donneront congé pour un temps si court, dont dépendra tant de profit: autrement stet ? ratione voluntas, L'obéissance ??dra?? qui sacrifié, Vous pouvez voir les raisons, que je leur donne in? Mes précédentes et s'il vous plaît m'obliger tant, qui de les piéger vous le pouviez fin qu'ils davantage à fin qu'ils n'interprètent pas mes actions ?a la rigueur. Cela qui m’afflige le plus c'est l'affliction de ma mère qui, je sais bien, se tourmentera devant mon absence; mais si elle considère la breveté du temps l'honneur et le profit qui en dépend, avir ? mes ?? prtestations? De ne la quitter pas, j'espère que lke teps, le raison et la piété adoucira ce mal. ?? S'il viousplaisait d'appliqer de vos rémèdes (de vos consolations) je m'ass?? Que tout ira bien et que je ne faillirai pas d'avoir son sonentiment à mes dessins, wui ne resonat jamais autres qu'honorables et profitables au public. Si je peux avoir du temps à ??? ?a Monsieur de ????m je ne manquerai pas à lui baiser les mains cependant prénetez liui ma ??? pareillement à monsieur ?? Monsieur docteur Hoffmann, Monsieur docteur Bauhin etc. Pur des nouvelles, Allemagne et laFrance vous fournit assez, dont j'attendrai les vôtres et me commande ?a vos graces, étant, ainsique votre très humble et obéissant serviteur, JJ Frey

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 3 October 1633
Bibliographical reference: CM? Transcription Regula Hohl, spelling normalized Dungarvan to Cork [copy of November 5] Date: 1633-10-03 Place: Leyden
Text: For want of opportunity after my last (which I send your lordship from Lyons) hath hindered my from giving your lordship that account of my voyage which you do expect from me [...] And I went straight to Basel, where I arrived 5 days afore, Mr. Frey would by no means ? me to lodge in inns, but provided for me a kinsman's house of his where we were lodged and etertained more like Princes than travellers. Amd visited by all his friends and kindred whom of the town is full. I met there two of my Lord of Warwick's sons, who are governed by Mr Battier and have followed at Basel 5 months their exercises. My intention was not to stay above ten days there but Mr Frey's long absence from his mother ... could not admit so sudden a departure, and besides the danger which we were like to run into if we were to pass through so many troops with so ?= compandy made me retard my voyage a mponth and have the merchant's company to Frankfort, during ? my stay there I made a step? To Zurich to ? upon the Duke of Rohan and to see the Kings' ? who is my special friend, but the Duke's occasions had celled hom from thence, to Chur, the chief town of the Grisons, where with his forces he was resolved to ... Howsoever I went there with Mr Fleming who I assure your Lordship does the King great service in those parts. Presently after my return from thence, I left Basel and went

Title: The New Testament in Greek
Bibliographical reference: Tēs Kainēs Diathēkēs hapanta: = Novi Testamenti Libri omnes : recens nunc editi : Variae item Lectiones ex antiquissimis exemplaribus & celeberrimis Bibliothecis, desumptae / Cum Notis & Animadversionibus Doctissimorum, Praesertim vero Roberti Stephani, Josephi Scaligeri, Isaaci Casauboni. London: R. Whittaker, 1633. UB, UBH Frey-Gryn A V 1:1
Text:
The copy of this book held in the Library of Basel University carries the signature of Johann Jacob Frey II and marginal notes in his hand.
In the Gospels (p. 1-147), Frey added one-word Latin chapter titles famous "stories" such as the Samaritan woman. Possibyl especially interesting: 74-75, 80, 99, 101, 103-109, 113, 115, 117, 119, 121, 124, 127, 130, 133, 137, 139, 143, 146, 148 and then 327-329!!!. The Letters and Acts of the Apostles are unmarked. Interesting: does he call parallel stories the same?

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 1 January 1633
Text:
Summary in Chatsworth catalogue
Found the air of the town agree so ill with him that he has been forced to take a lodging in the Fauxbourg, where he has M. de Memnon for riding-master, and M. Porvost for dancing. The Cardinal arrived yesterday with all the nobility attending on him; the King comes tomorrow, the Queen yet mourns for her brother. Longs to hear his opinion of Her Majesty's comedy, and begs him to send it in his next letter, but to say no more of it than it deserves. Has no more to say.
Line reference: @100392 Letter to the Earl of Cork 1 January 1633

Title: Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork 2 August 1633
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth CM17/157 Transcription Regula Hohl TrilliniJohann Jacob Frey to Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork Date: 1633-08-02 Place: Lyons
Text: Tomorrow, which will be the 3rd of August [1633], we shall leave this town, God willing, and go toward Geneva, three days' journey from hence; where we pass? ? 2 days and afterwards go to Basel. By which way, my lordship shall see Lausanne, Biel, Fribourg, Zurich and Solothurn. At Zurich is the King's agent Mr. Fleming, and my Duke of Rohan, which will bid my Lordship welcome, I know. [page 6] At Basel I will keep my lord a little to himself, till I may hear from your Lordship (if it be possible) upon my letter from Saumur. Afterwards we take the commodity of the river of Rhine, to go down into the Low Countries and if ? ? Prince Palatione be at Heidelberg, it will be in our way to wait upon him a while, which my Lord Dungarvan doth intend. I am glad to embrace tjhis occasion to ? the time ? nothing may be undertaken without your Lordship's special command or approbation. Where my lordship's honour and safety is in questions. I have left such order here at Lyons and with
Comment: This letter comes at the end of a list of travel destinations and expenses.

Lyons in great haste this 2nd of August
Be pleased, Madam, to take share of my letter to my Lord of Cork at this time, which suffered me not to say anything more

Title: Doctrina Temporum
Bibliographical reference: Bucherius, Aegidius. Doctrina Temporum. 1634.
Text: Doctrina Temporum
Comment: Bucherius was born in Arras. His Doctrina Temporum from 1634 published for the first time some important chronological documents, in particular the Chronography of 354, and work on computation of the date of Easter (the cycle of Victorius of Aquitaine). He also published Anatolius Laodicensis and Hippolytus Romanus. Originally at Béthune, he moved to Liège, where for six years he was Rector of the College. He died in Tournai.
Line reference: @100187 Doctrina Temporum
Subject: History, (auto-)biography

Title: Letter to Lady Frances Clifford 12 September 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 17 and 18 Microfilm pdf p. 25 anscription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford to Lady Frances Clifford Date 1634-09-12 Place: Dublin
Text:
Madam,
your Ladyship is still pleased to extend your goodness towards me, far beyond any merits of mine which yet I am able to consider and value, and shall ever awaken all the powers that are in me, that we I may in sum measure become worthy of your Ladyship's esteem. We daily expect to receive the honour of your noble daughters' arrival on this site, and by none I am sure more earnestly waited or than myself. I shall infinitely desire to serve her Ladyship, as in nothing more convened since I came into this kingdom, then to think I may be so happy as to pay her Ladyship some of those duties I owe her and that house which I profess to honour more than that of any other [?]. And I beseech your Ladyship rest assured you have not in the whole world more absolute command over any other creature, than with [me]
Dublin this 12th of September 1634
Your Ladyship's most faithful and most humble servant.
Strafford, Thomas
Line reference: @100058 Letter to Lady Frances Clifford 12 September 1634

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork July 1634
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth collection
Text:
tbe
Lord Clifford and Lord Strange are going to take him to Newcastle to wait on the King and Queen, and he has only an hour to write this letter in. Lord Clifton has promised to hasten their departure immediately after returning from the Progress. Either Mr Frey or himself will go to London to take order with his creditors. Begs credit on Alderman Parkhurst or others for the amount. They are: Mr John Crew, Remainder received in France - £500; Mr Andrew Varley for Jewels - £270; Mr Allyn, Goldsmith in Fleet Street - £320; Mr Shallcross - £200; Mrs Burton, widow, milliner - £230; Mr Perkins, for clothes, about - £700; The coachmaker and other petty debts - £200. Total: £2,420. Supposes his lordship has prevented his entreaties for furnishing of some chambers with beds and hangings. What coach-horses and charges in journey home will come to, his lordship best knows, and therefore he begs him to be mindful of it.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 25 February 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 48-49 Microfilm pdf p. 64 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Lady Elizabeth Dungarvan to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1634-02-25 Place: Lismore Castle
Text:
Lismore this 25 of Febr: 1634
Mr. Frey
I received a letter from you where you expressed much sleepiness which I might guess by some of the sense since so reasonable a man as you are quite awake would hardly make so unrea-sonable a request as yours was to make your word good in that which is not in the power of any living. If I had a mind to quarrel this might serve a sufficient ground but I shall so much shun all occasions of defiance with you that in here you have resolved I was with child if you confess your error proceeded out of your desire of having it so and from no other ground I am satisfied and here the quarrel ends. These letters for my father we direct to you because I fear he is gone into the North and then I hope you will send them instantly by the carrier to York or by some more speedy messenger.
I am sorry I could not perform your possible request to excuse you to the Master of the Rolls [?] being so far from him but when you desire anything more important no [in margin from now on] distance shall hinder me from performing faithfully whatsoever you desire which may confirm your belief [?] him. pray send these letters to my servant Dumoulin [?] Your faithful Friend and servant [My D. Dungarvan]
Line reference: @100029 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 25 February 1634

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 18 February 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 32 Microfilm pdf p. 47 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized John Bramhall to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1634-02-18
Text:
Sir
I am to give you many thanks both for the safe and speedy delivery of my letters as also for your extraordinary care in my affairs, which I wish myself able to make an acknowledgment of by any service of mine in those parts. I remember I told you when you were home that I know but our meddlement to [?] your desires of that particular preferment you desired to your feet. Now I may be you that that [trouble?] is my [?] to be removed. And that engagement to be taken of with the dowry of Limerick so that if the other fall or any other thing in the interim that I shall concern wor-thy of you. I will be your [rememberer?].
Our parliament goes on how most prosperously 4 or 6 bills pass a day without any [demand?] or [discord?]. The opposite plyes[applies?] seeing by experience of the left position their own weakness.
Yesterday the cause was heard between my Lord [name] and [?] [?] three [?] by carriages but not sentenced until tomorrow. Howsoever we that were bystanders thought it clean enough. And if it were not too much presumption too divine we believe others were of that opinion also. My Lord Dungarvan and his noble Lady are still in the country, both will god be praised.
I beseech you if it be possible by your next [?] your city intelligence. And gained [?] my Lord Mayor's answer. Great bodies move slowly And if you sprinkle in some German or foreign news it will be grateful to us that live removed in this other world.
I suppose the messenger that brings these will return with speed. I pray your answer and remain.
Your most affectionate friend
Johannes Derensis
Dublin Castle febr. 18. 1634.
[in margin:] My Wife thanks you and Dean Culme and his joy a [?] [?] to understand your welfare
Line reference: @100099 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 18 February 1634
Modifications: NaHu#007055 Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan / NaHu#007057 Lady Elizabeth Dungarvan

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 20 February 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 40 Microfilm pdf p. 56 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized James Ussher to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1634-02-20
Text:
Salutem in Christo Jesu
Since the sending of my two last letters unto you by the packet: I received yours of the 19th of January, which brought me the welcome news of the arriving of the MSS volumes [ink blots and crossed out words] have taken order with Mr. Rickesis, that on [ink] twenty pounds[? ink] shall presently be remitted unto you by bill of exchange. I know not how sufficiently express my thankfulness to that unknown Civilian, who was pleased so far to reject me, as be commit unto the adventure of the seas those other rare writings of the same argument. [?] for your discharge, and for your better saving[?] of such worthy moments: I wish that they be not committed to a new hazard of being sent over hither, but that Burnett may take care that they be transcribed in London by some that hath knowledge in the French tongue, and that the originals of the transcripts having been first carefully collated therewhilst I may afterwards be from thence (with great think) remitted unto the owner.
I sent you a note therefore, when I thought you intended a journey towards Florence, touching the collation of Ignatius his Epistles with the Greek Manuscript there. It may be you may hear of Sirmondus or some others, that there is some Manuscript thereof to be found at Paris. If there be; I should be much beholden to your Cousin Battier (though I am far in his debt for kindness already) for taking some pains to collate the same with the printed book. for I [ink] very desirous to publish Ignatius free from those additions which the later Grecious have [ink] […] not be uncertain conjectures (as Vedelius hath done) but the authority of written copies. I would have you take your opportunity of visiting my Lord of Canterbury for he writes unto me that when you delivered unto him my letters, he was going to Court and so had no time to speak with you then. The picture is long since finished; as you desired. which is a poor recompense for your great love and knowledge by you […] unto me: for which I must still remain Your debtor,
Ja[mes] Armachanus
Dublin Febr, 20. 1634
Line reference: @100100 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 20 February 1634
Modifications: NaHu#007079 Abraham Rickesis / NaHu#007083 Jacob Battier

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 4 May 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 28-29 Microfilm pdf p. 41-42 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Alessandro Lattanzi, spelling normalized John Gregory to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1634-05-04 Place: Oxford
Text:
Sir
The estimation you made[or make?] of my acquaintance is […] above any cause of encouragement which can be found in me and therefore I must take you’re the opinion of that […] matter of [?] discoursing word of your own Christianity[?] than any dissert[?] of [?] what happiness and advantage I consider myself to have in my dotation[?] on [?] your Acquaintance I hope ere long to find an [?] how I may express you this great encouragement [?] I [receive?] from you I proceed to trouble you The sections you meet with I myself made bold to also [=add] my Author in your [=ye, the] MSS. being now otherwise divided them [=thro’, through] into whole books which [?] call the [?] [=which he calleth λόγους ]. The best diversion [=direction?] I can think of this the Chronicon Alexandrinum set fourth by Rader at Monachium or Munchen in Bavaria 1624 hath very much of my coppy word for word from page 84 to page 115 it is all out of my Author save the 2 first leaves 85 and 88 for that which follows differ not at all but in a varia lectio and in the order which in the Chronicon Alexandrinum is more confused so that if anything be found of these things which are usually let down by Chronographers [between?] Adam and that […] of storie which you shall meet within Chronicon Alexandrinum at p. 84. Ἐν τοῖϛ χρόνοιϛ etc. be assured that is wanting. Again 29 [NB: ‘29’ from outside the page margin] in the Trojan Wars I want a leafe or two about that of Palamedes –ρεν ἐκ τῆϛ κινήσεωϛ τῶν ἑπτά πλανητῶν κατά μοιρικὴν τύχην, etc. concerning that device of his which is there called τάβλα, after which followeth the character of Meriones then of Ideomeneus then of Philoctetes etc. The place before this where my MSS […] thus, καὶ λαβεῖν τὸν Πολύδωρον υἱὸν αὐτοῦ καὶ γενέσθαι εἰρήνην, etc. Again from the 10[th] booke and so forward My MSS hath the Imperial hist[ory] to Justinian of whose life it hath much and yet goes not far for that being of the Author’s own time how sets[?] it down at large therefore from the beginning of Justinian’s life and forward as far as my Author goes is all wanting and I doubt in many places of that which I have for my Copy is very false written. Concerning the place of Damascen [sic] it is in his 3[rd] oration De imaginibus were [=where?] amongst many others of the life [?] argument he sets docouo [=possibly decore, ‘suitably’ or ‘in a pleasing manner’?] the storie of the haemorrhoisa [next page] which he says he had out of Johannes Antiochenus-Malala and his tone [=’tis true?] for my Copy bears [=beneath] him writes [=witness(s)?] at the 20[th] booke where that life [=hist(ory)] is related word for word almost as it is found in Damascene. Having thus laid upon the [dissasent?] [=diseases?] of my MSS, I am [from now on, writing from the front presses through, hard to read] bold to have the cure to the differences[?] and the good opportunity which may you profoundly[?] have not in the matter [?] but in all [?] rest[?] of the most glorious [?]! And for anything which you may think worthy of use [?] among [?] if the matter come with my Compass[?] empoyment[?] and withal [?] sure that you have committed the business[?] to whose incomparable [?] of you has found such […] in your false that it can […] possible that you [?] be neglected […] you shall be pleased to call for an experience of that great[?] interest which you shall have.
Ch[rist] Ch[urch], Oxford
May 4. 1634
the assured and most content friend
to do you service
Joh. Gregorio
Comment:
A.L.’s note: Chronicon Alexandrinum, idemque astronomicum et ecclesiasticum, ed. Matthäus Rader, Munich: Berg, 1615. It was reissued unchanged in 1624, with the new date printed on a pasted-in slip.
A.L.’s note: ‘from the movement of the seven planets, according to the destiny assigned them by chance’ (John Malalas, Chronographia, V, 9; ed. Johannes Thurn, Berlin and New York: de Gruyter, 2000 (Corpus Fontium Historiae Byzantinae, 35: Series Berolinensis), p. 77). The gap in the manuscript described by Gregory is shown in the Oxford MS of Malalas’ Chronographia (Bodleian Library, MS Barocci 182), where one leaf is lost between fol. 48v, καὶ οὐχ εἴλοντο, and fol. 49r, ***ρεν ἐκ τῆϛ κινήσεωϛ. See the beginning of fol. 49r:
The manuscript was purchased by William Herbert, 3rd earl of Pembroke, Chancellor of Oxford University, and then presented to the University in 1629. See Elizabeth Jeffreys, ‘The Transmission of Malalas’ Chronicle’, in Studies in John Malalas, ed. Elizabeth Jeffreys, Brian Croke and Roger Scott, Sydney: Australian Association for Byzantine Studies, 1990 (Byzantina Australiensia, 6), pp. 245–311, especially 245-246.
A.L.’s note: a sort of game of dice, reportedly invented by Palamedes (John Malalas, Chronographia, V, 9).
Translator’s note: ‘and take his son Polydorus, and make peace’ (John Malalas, Chronographia, V, 8), ed. Thurn, p. 75. The tale is different from Homer’s (Iliad, XXII).
A.L.’s note: John Damascene, De imaginibus oratio III, in Patrologia Graeca, vol. 94, cols. 1317–1420.
A.L.’s note: viz. αἱμορροῦσα, ‘the bleeding woman’ mentioned by the Synoptics (Matthew 9, 20–22; Mark 5, 25–34; Luke 8, 43–48). However, the legend of the bleeding woman reported by Malalas (Chronographia, X, 11–12; ed. Thurn, pp. 179–181) is only loosely derived from the Gospels.
A.L.’s note: De imaginibus, III, cols. 1369–1374, explicitly quoting the Chronographia of John of Antioch, whom Damascene confuses with Malalas (Ἰωάννου Ἀντιοχείας, τοῦ καὶ Μαλάλα, ‘of John of Antioch, also known as Malalas’).

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 14 January 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 38-39 Microfilm pdf p. 53-54. Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Alessandro Lattanzi, spelling normalized. James Ussher to Johann Jacob Frey
Text:
Salute in Christo Jesu
I received your letter from Holyhead; and was very pleased to understand hereby your safe arrival. What you desire concerning the picture, shall be performed. for I may not deny you anything dear at home, who are so ready to do all things for me abroad. Aegidius Bucherius hath inserted into his commentary upon Victorius his Paschal Canon printed at Antwerp, anno 1633. pag. 244 a Collection of an ancient author, consisting of these five particulars.
I. A catalogue of Consuls, from the years of our Lord 205 ad 354. (pag. 247) una cum Paschali centum annorum Laterculo ab anno 312 ad 411. (pag. [hole in paper?])
II. Nomina Praefectorum Urbis Romae, ab anno 254 ad 354. (pag. 236)
III. Parvum Martyrologium. (pag. 267)
IV. A Catalogue of the Bishops of Rome, from S. Peter to Liberius. (pag. 269)
V. An Ancient Roman Calendar. (pag. 275) the same that was before published by Hewart.
The fourth of these Petavius [Dionysius Petavius?] saith he had: (lib. II. de doctrina temporum, cap. 21. pag. 332) which I would desire might be compared that which is printed, and the differences sent unto me. It were also good to learn of him, whence he had his copies and whether that had not the rest also of the forenamed treatises, as well as this fourth. for all of them are worth the comparing with other manuscripts: The first especially, which wanted the beginning; from the first Consuls until those of the year of our Lord 205. Sirmondus also may enquire of [?] the same: who said two other manuscripts, where of I desire (whether by your own, or by some others means) you would procure me a transcript. They are these.
I. Idatii episcopi Fastorum consularium pars prima et ultima, for the middle part only he caused to be printed together with Idatius his Chronicle, at Paris anno 1619 (viz. ab exordio Aureliani Augusti ad obitum Honorii) but the rest, how faulty [?], I should desire might be transcribed for my wife.
II. Excerptum anonymi scriptoris, continens brevem historiam temporum Constantii Chlori et Constantini Magni filii eius (cited by Petavius, De doctrina temporum, pars 2, pag. 712)
He has also another Manuscript, containing a Collection of diverse treatises concerning Cyclos et rationes Paschales: most whereof have been already published by Petavius and Bucberius. Of those that remain unpublished I desireonly to know the titles and the first words: that I may compare them with those which I have of the same kind, as yet unprinted. He likewise hath the last part of Propers Chronicle which is not yet printed. I should be glad to know whether there be anything in it [on the side margin: ab anno Christi [cut off]6 et 448.] touching the first coming of the Saxons into Britain, for the [?] of the natives there against the Picts and Scots. In his notes upons Facundus pag. 32. a. (edit. Paris anno 1629) he promised the publication of Leporius his libellus satisfactionis ad Gallos episcopos: which if you see is not likely to be shortly affected, it would not be amiss to procure copies of it. He cites also (as I remember) in his notes upon Sidonius Apollinaris, the commentaries of Sedulius upon Matthew. I pray you learn of him where they are to be found: and if you can come to a [?] of them, take a note of what he writes upon Matth. XVI. 18,19. and XXVI. 26,27,28,29. [I] would willingly be at the changes of the transcribing of the whole work, if I could [have] it copied. In his notes upon the Gallican Councils, he cited these manuscripts.
I. Hincmari opera varia in codice manu scripto Laurentii Leodicensis (wherein if there be any that does concern the cause of Gotteschalcum; you know the copy thereof would stand me in some steed for the finishing of the second edition of his history.
II. Eiusdem Hincmari posterius opus adversus Gotteschalchum et Praedestinatianos; together with other treatises written by him of the same argument in codice manu scripto Bibliothecae S. Remigii apud Remenses; one of these also I think is cited by Rigaltius, among the testimonies which he placed [at the] beginning of his edition of Tertullian in folio. If either by his, or Sirmondus his direction, you can settle a course for obtaining a copy of these things (if it fall not out of that they have been lately printed) you should herein do me a very great pleasure.
III. Eiusdem Hincmari scripta in hac causa alia, in quibus et Rabani ad illum epistola, in codice manu scripto Ecclesiae S. Mariae Laudunensis.
IV. Johannis Eriugenae Scoti De unica praedestinatione liber, capitulum XIX, ad Hincmarum et Pardulum episcopos. Manuscriptus in bibliotheca Corbeiensi.
Nicolaus Camuzatius , who set out the Antiquities Ecclesiae Tricassinae (of whom you may learn by Sirmondus , Mr. du Chesne , and others there) hath diverse other things which concern this cause of Gotteschalcus, and among the rest, Prudentii Tricassini episcopi opusculum contra Johannem Scotum, which he promised to publish. If you can procure nothing from him: you may have a copy transcribed for me of this last work of Prudentius, ex Thuani bibliotheca [‘from the library of Thuanus’ now in the possession of Puteanorum fratrum. In which library you shall also find, Rathranni liber contra Graecos, et De corpore et sanguine Domini. The former whereof it was thought that Sirmondus would have published before now; together with Hincmar of Reims and Aeneas of Paris, touching the same argument. You may enquire of himself what he intends to do therein: and cause copies to be taken of them, if he means not to have them printed. The other De corpore et sanguine Domini is that which commonly goes under the name of Bertram: which I would desire your kinsman to transcribe, out of Thuanus his MS and afterwards carefully compare with another MS of the same which Mr. Casaubon told me he saw in bibliotheca D. Jacobi Giloti senatoris Parisiensis , if yet that may be found.
Either in that of Thuanus or in other libraries at Paris there is to be had Anastasii Bibliothecarii Historia Ecclesiastica: the preface whereof beginneth thus. “Ecclesiasticam (charissime frater et digne Christi Levita Joannes) auctore Deo scripturus historiam”, etc. then follows Chronologia Nicephori episcopi Constantinopolitani, beginning from Adam. Which Preface and Chronology being passed over, I desire that the former part of the following work of Anastasius may be transcribed for me, until the beginning of the empire of Theodosius the younger (ev. [?]) Petavius will tell you, where it may be had: who in his Preface before Nicephori Constantinopolitani Patriarchae Breviarium historicum (editum Parisiis anno 1616) put us in hope that Theophanes his chronicle (out of which Anastasius hath translated most of his) should have been published in Greek, long ere this. You may tell him, that he cannot do a thing more acceptable to those that are studious of the ancient histories, then to publish the Chronicle of Georgius Syncellus (which is in the French King’s library) together with his continuator Theophanes: although he set it out at first in Greek only, without any Latin translation or Notes. And if you find him backward therein: you may make the like motion unto Rigaltius, or some other industrious man of your acquaintance there. A great part of Georgius is already transcribed unto their hand, by Josephus Scaliger in his Greek Eusebius and Notes upon him: which may save the transcriber a great deal of labour. And thus much concerning manuscripts. Some printed books I can not get in England: which peradventure you may light upon at Paris. as
Hieronymi Vecchietti De anno primitivo et de sacrorum temporum ratione libri 8. printed Augustae Vindelicorum (Petavius had one of them: and either by his or some others [sic] means you may perhaps gett another)
Eusebius et caeteri Ecclesiasticae Historiae scriptores a Curterio editi (printed in Paris, I thinke)
Francisci Vietae Calendarium Gregorianum (both the editions of it.)
Antonius Augustinus in Codicem Canonicum ab Hadriano I Papa e***[marginal rip]
Pauli Alexandrini Astrologica, Graece edita.
Fr. Pithoei Notae in Legem Salicam.
Theobaldi Meuschii Chronologia.
[In margin]
You see I have written as far as my payer [prayer?] would give me leave: and more works a great deal [ink makes two words unreadable] I should impose upon you; but that you yourself would need, I have it so. I pray you write unto me when you leave Paris, and signify unto me in what forwardness the great Bible is. God almighty have you in his keeping; and bless you on your journey.
Dublin Jan. 14. 1634
Your own as you know
Ja[mes] Armachanus

Title: Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan October 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. Microfilm pdf p. Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Johann Jacob Frey to Dungarvan Date: 1634-10 or later Place: Lismore Castle
Text:
My dearest and most honoured Lord,
Your Lordship's kind letter of the 12th of September from Lismore hath restored me again to the true value[?] of your Lordship's constancy, which by reason of your silence, the apprehension of my own unworthiness caused me to dispute a while: I may say it truly nothing could have raised my dejected spirits to such a cordial joy, as the assurance of your Lordship's love, which (I thank god) my heart shall never esteem by any outward preferment so much, as the continual presence[?] of your affection. This I hold the greatest [?] in the world, and make it the subject of my daily prayers that I may not lose it at this distance: which your Lordship may confidently believe, would soon end the hopes of the servant, of ever seeing Ireland again. What in my letter to my Lady, I have been bold to say, I beseech your Lordship to take in good part, and recede myself, and what may forever be called mine into your protection, being yours as many ways, as I have means to subsist. This country is so pitifully exhausted of all necessaries, and groans yet under the burden of continual armies, that pass either through it, or lodge in it, [?] I shall have much trouble to sell what I have here. And when I have done all, my engagement to the public (besides what respects I owe to my mother and the rest of my friends) is such that nothing but my Lord Deputy's and my Lord Primate's letter can procure my liberty here, which when I have, I shall rejoice to return to your Lordship and take possession of the place I now have in the church of Ireland, only be pleased, my Lordship, to join hands with my Lady in Procuring the things mentioned to her in my letter, and the rest is news [end of page].
Line reference: @100023 Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan October 1634
Modifications: NaHu#007002 James Ussher / NaHu#007040 Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford

Title: Ephemerides January 1634
Bibliographical reference: Hartlib, Samuel. Ephemerides. 1634 Part 1, 1 January or later. 29/2/1A-11B: 1B BLANK URL: https://www.dhi.ac.uk/hartlib/view?docset=main&docname=29_02_01&term0=transtext_frey#highlight Last accessed 1 June 2021 [normalized spelling].
Text: Mr Frey told me Mr D[ury] that Ussher had absolved and ready for the press his Ecclesiastical Work which is a Critica Sacra Historia Ecclesiæ et Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum. Duræus Libri Theologici Vsherus MS. It is a great work and I fear rather to be desired than expected in this perverse Age, neither can I conceive what any private Men can do in it except the Princes of Germany (who can mould their Countries to any Religion at their pleasure for the most part) consent to have the true Opinions debated and submit to what shall bee concluded to be the truth.
