Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 12 September 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 58 Microfilm pdf p. 75 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Dungarvan to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1634-09-12 Place: Lismore Castle
Text:
Honest Mr. Frey
I have received many letters and favours from you but have made not answered nor returned no expressions of thankfulness [smudged] for them, this I desire you process not out of any forgetfulness but out of desire I had to give the [?] assurance of the good news which I am confident will hasten your return unto us, and therefore know that the old dean of Armagh is fallen asleep as your divines call it, or dead as we term it, and my lord Deputy has already signed the patent for your [enjoying?] of it which he intends to send us a present to [wife?], this I write unto you that you may prepare yourself and instruct me what I shall do to facilitate your coming [in margin] over. We have no news here but that my father [?] chamber business is in a fair way of accommodating God and us well of. We shall[?] spend this winter in Ireland where the happiness of your conversation would be much welcome[partially cut off] Your most [smudged word] [cut off word] Dungarvan [upside down] Lismore this 12 September 1634 [partially crossed out] my service to all my friends of Basel
Comment: check the date
Line reference: @100024 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 12 September 1634
Modifications: NaHu#007080 Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey January 1634
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 46 Microfilm pdf p. 62 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1634-01
Text:
Honest Mr. Frey
The last I sent onto you was written in haste just hast, now I have more [?] I will let you know that my father is gone to Dublin and I remain here a famous housekeeper. The cause there is good for I both hope and believe that my wife is withheld, and how dangerous such a journey might prove, Mrs. [Frane?] will tell you. I pray speak not a word of this for as yet there is no certainty at all. My father and I have had a of late many [?] which I believe proceed from the affection he supposes I fear you having of late had some occasion to [?] money I also his [faded] for my half year's allowance, which had [leered?] due unto me this three months, his [faded] answer was th[cut off] I must not think that he would pay my [cut off] and que me my allowance and this all [?] instead of payment. I hope his [lp?] will not always be at this pass for if he [cut off] we shall not long be together.
[upside down] I pray let me know how I shall address my letters which are to be sent into Germany. Send me over my gold chain as soon as you can and a receipt [?] how to boil a carp and make sauce unto it. Till you send me word what you have done with [?] I cannot hope [?] for the pay of the interest [left margin] [becomes hard to read as he is scrambling for space] I hope you have by this time almost [?] yours and my business I pray remember[faded] to [?] [faded] Mr. B[name] Mr. Derkyns[?] bonds which he had of my Lord Ranelagh and myself and the letters of attorney I made you when you went from Skipton [? faded] to London. I pray let me know what discharge I have from Mr. Harwood [faded] for the money my father pays and what discharge I shall expect from Mr. Smith when I pay the 500 and 80 pounds I shall be glad to know what [Lady?] Mervyn says unto you, and whether Ball has given you a bond and what you have done with Lorenzo Cary[?]. Mr. Frey as I do trouble you with all these things shall I be glad to request [?] do [?] you any service which may show me yours
Dungarvan
Line reference: @100025 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey January 1634

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 14 April 1634
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth CM 18, fol. 2, published in Lismore Papers Vol. 3, 1888, pp.193-194. Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Dungarvan to Cork Date: 1634-04-14 Place: London
Text:
My most honoured lord Father
[On his first coming to Londesborough feared by his lady's strangeness, it would be a work of great difficulty to gain her good opinion, but by his observances and pleasing of her humor, believes he was won her approbation in the business and her desire that it may be finished. Thinks himself the most happy creature alive in having such a mistress. The Lord Clifford used him very nobly, and hath sent up all his evidences, desiring to see the happy consummation of this business]

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 20 September 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 21 Microfilm pdf p. 29-30 Transcription and translation Alessandro Lattanzi Christoph Lüthard to Johann Jacob Frey Date:1635-09-20  Place: Bern
Text:
Greetings in the name of Christ.
As you write, most illustrious sir, I have just received your very elegant letter at the same time as that from Mr. Spanheim. I would have already responded, if the public notaries, whose certification has been required by Mr. Spanheim, and in whose hands the History of the Waldensians is held, had not been late. Indeed, only a few of ours master Italian language, and those few involved in public affairs, and proceed rather slowly in collating this huge work with the autograph; nor did I fail to admonish them, so that I can satisfy your request as soon as possible. I beg you, therefore, not to ascribe my silence to either unkindness or carelessness from me, whom you will find most ready to oblige you in anything. As far as it concerns the fee to be paid to Gottfried Metzger, I asked others for their opinion, and having examined his work, they allege that he deserved at least 20 Reichstaler. I have no doubt that yourself will not evaluate the work otherwise. Being he a very poor man and unable to support his family, I have thus far paid 10 Reichstaler. As for the rest, under what conditions Mr. Lentulus gave the permission to publish this history, written by his grandfather of pious memory, I shall explain to you when I send it in to you. 20th September 1635 Yours most faithfully and respectfully, Christoph Lüthardt
Comment:
NOTE Lüthardt recommended the young Johann Heinrich Hummel for a grant to go and study abroad 1633

Address, fol. 21v: Viro clarissimo atque praestantissimo Domino Johanni Jacobo Freyio, in illustri Academia Basileensi Graecae linguae professori solertissimo. Basel.
Note in J. J. Frey’s hand, fol. 21v: "1635. 30. 7br.’"
Lüthard is aopologiyzing for the delay in copying Scipio Lentulus' Historia delle grandi e crudeli persecutioni … contra il popolo che chiamano valdese, the "history of the dreadful and cruel persecutions of the community of the so-called Waldenses". See also: letters of 17 Dec. 1635 and 4 Feb. 1636.
Line reference: @100044 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 20 September 1635
Modifications: NaHu#007029 Friedrich Spanheim / NaHu#007088 Scipio Lentulus / NaHu#007089 Julius Caesar Lentulus / NaBo@100082 The History of the Waldensians / NaHu#007090 Vitus Gottfried Metzger
URL:
Salutem plurimam in Christo.
Sic est ut scribis, clarissime vir, humanissimas tuas literas simul cum iis quas Dominus Spanhemius ad me dederat pronuper accepi. Ad quas iam respondissem nisi me notarii publici, quorum testimonium requisivit Dominus Spanhemius, et in quorum manibus Historia Waldensium haeret, retardassent. Sunt enim nostris qui linguam Italicam teneant pauci, iique publicis negotiis implicati, quique in prolixi huius operis cum autographo collatione tardiuscule procedant. Nec destiti illos monere ut petitioni tuae quam primum satisfacere possem. Quapropter te summopere rogo ne hoc meum silentium vel incivilitati vel negligentiae adscribas meae, quem in quovis officiosum genere habebis paratissimum. De salario Gothofredi Mezgeri aliorum rogavi iudicium, qui inspectione operis facta viginti imperiales ad minimum promeruisse asserunt. Nec puto te uti opus ipsum videris aliter iudicaturum. Ego ei, cum sit homo pauperrimus et alendae familiae insufficiens, decem adhuc imperiales persolvi. Caeterum quibus conditionibus Dominus Lentulus hanc ab avo suo piae memoriae conscriptam Historiam typis mandari permiserit, tibi aperiam cum eam tibi transmisero. Tu interim, clarissime vir, vale quam optime, et me tui amantissimum inter amicos tuos esse patiare. Dabam XX Septembris MDCXXXV Tuus omni officio et cultu Christophorus Lüthardtus

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 17 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 22-23 Microfilm pdf p. 31-33 Transcription and translation Alessandro Lattanzi (spelling normalized) Christoph Lüthardt to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-09-08 Place: Bern
Text:
Greetings in the name of Christ.
Most illustrious and erudite man, I received at the right time your letter, where it is indicated through whom I can safely send you the History of the Waldenses. It was in the hands of the public notaries, who subjected it to a thorough scrutiny and authenticated it by their signatures, as suggested by Mr. Spanheim to guarantee the veracity of the History. Being ignorant of the Italian language, I had nothing to do with the History, but based on what the notaries reported, I cannot, in the first place, but warn Your Excellency against what seems to me to speak to the early faith of the Reformed Church and the Waldensians. In the eighth, that is the last book, Lentulus inserted an invective speech, in which he accuses his own [parishioners] at Angrogna, and almost in general the Waldensians, of many crimes, incest, depravity, undbridled lust and licentiousness, even incestuous relationships with their own children, infanticide, and other such things. If what I have just remarked here is to be send overseas, I leave you, most prudent man, to consider more carefully. I have no doubt about the devotion of the Archbishop, even less so about his circumspection, so that I am persuaded that he will never make these things known. However, according to the proverb, writings remain, and after his death the History might possibly pass into the hands of other people, who would either accuse the Archbishop of having falsified the history if he left these facts out, or in turn make them publicly known to the detriment of the Waldensians, as they wish. But as I said, the final decision will be upon you. As for the History itself, Mr. Lentulus consented to give it under no other condition but that of making mention of his grandfather Scipio Lentulus as the author, and sending the manuscript of the History back to him. Nobody will deny that both of the conditions are fair. It is written with a rather blunted pen, thus resulting in a handwriting that is less easy to grasp at first glance, but a careful reading of the very first page suffices to lead the reader to understand it. In addition to the 10 Reichstaler that the copyist received from Your Excellency, so far I have paid a further 10 for half the paper and 5 for the public notaries, who spent eight full days in the collation and correction of the writing errors and copious quotes from the sacred writings. I have not seen the small book you make mention of in your letter. I have learned this at least from Mr. Lentulus: that this History was lost many years before the synod held in Dauphiné, but I could gain no certain information as to how it happened. Be pleased, most illustrious man, with this little letter of mine, and even in greater things, count for sure on all my zeal to serve you. Be well.
The 17th December 1635
Your Excellency's most faithful
Christoph Lüthardt
Comment:
ADDRESS (fol. 23 verso): Clarissimo literatissimoque viro Domino Johanni Jacobo Freyo in illustri Academia Basileensi Graecae linguae professori doctissimo, Domino et Pastori honorando. Basel.
Not in Johann Jacob Frey's hand (fol. 23 verso): "antwort. (4/14) Febr. 1636."

Modifications: NaHu#007002 James Ussher / NaHu#007029 Friedrich Spanheim / NaCo#009035 Waldenses / NaHu#007088 Scipio Lentulus / NaHu#007089 Julius Caesar Lentulus / NaBo@100082 The History of the Waldensians
URL:
Salutem plurimam in Christo.
Percommode tuas accepi, clarissime atque literatissime vir, quibus indicatum per quem Historiam Waldensium tuto ad te mittere possem. In manibus ea fuit publicorum notariorum, qui eam summo studio perlustrarunt subsignaruntque αὐθεντικῶϛ, quod in fidem Historiae faciendum erat, monitore Domino Spanhemio. In tota Historia ego Italicae linguae ignarus hospes fui, sed ex relatione notariorum non possum quin hic primo Tuam Excellentiam moneam, quod ad Ecclesiae Reformatae et Waldensium antiquam fidem facere mihi videtur. Subiecit Dominus Lentulus in octavo, id est postremo libro concionem invectivam. In qua suos Angronianos et Waldenses fere generaliter accusat multorum criminum, incestus, scortationis, indomitae libidinis et licentiae, immo et ex incestu natorum, infanticidii, et si quae sunt his similia. Quae ego quidem notavi, tibi vero homini prudentissimo diligentius considerandum relinquo an haec ad transmarinos sint mittenda. De pietate Archiepiscopi mihi non dubium, minus de eius circumspecta prudentia, sic ut mihi persuadeam ipsum haec numquam divulgaturum. Quia vero litera scripta manent, ut est in proverbio, posset post ipsius mortem Historia in aliorum manus pervenire, qui vel Dominum Archiepiscopum falsatae historiae (si omitteret) accusarent, vel eadem in fraudem Waldensium denuo publice nota facerent, prout ingenium est adversariorum. Sed, ut dixi, iudicium penes te esto. Caeterum quod Historiam ipsam attinet, non alia conditione eam concedere voluit Dominus Lentulus quam ut avi sui Scipionis Lentuli tamquam autoris in ea fiat mentio, et ut exemplar Historiae ad se mittatur. Utrumque aequum esse nemo negabit. Descripta est obtusiori calamo, hinc character primo intuitu minus acceptus, sed ad eius cognitionem perducet lectorem vel primae paginae perlustratio. Praeter decem imperiales quos etiam scriptor a Tua Excellentia accepit, persolvi adhuc decem alios pro chartis dimidium, notariis publicis quinque, qui in collatione et sphalmatum graphicorum, mysticorumque pleonasticorum correctione dies integros octo consumpsere. Libellum cuius in literis mentionem facis, non vidi. Hoc saltem ex ore Domini Caesaris habeo, Synodum in Delphinatu ante bene multos annos congregatam hanc Historiam periisse, quam tamen certas ob causas non obtinuit. Tu, vir clarissime, hanc meam epistellam bene consule, et in maioribus etiam omnia officia a me indubitato exspecta et vale. Dabam XVII Decembris MDCXXXV Tuae Excellentiae officiosissimus Christophorus Lüthartus

Title: Letter to Thomas Littell 17 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 175 Microfilm pdf p. 263-264 Transcription Regula Hohl, spelling normalized Johann Jakob Frey to Thomas Littell Date: 1635-12-17 Place: Basel
Text:
Noble Sir,
Being to write as much in as little volume as I can possibly, you will be pleased to excuse me if I take but half a sheet to answer your kind letter fo the 17th of November? Last, which came to my hands about eight days ago [that was fast!] and brought me the news of what my most noble Lord the Lord Deputy gave me assurance at my departure. I have ignored??? Here several letters to express my humble and thankful acknowledgments to my Lord, which I do likewise in this and entreat you ??? to present my most humble services to his Lordship. when you receive this packet [...]. If you write to London, I pray you, enquire for it.
Comment: ENDNOTE A copy of my letter to Mr. Littell, my Lord Deputy's secretary

Title: Letter to John Bramhall 17 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 171, Microfilm pdf p. 255-256 Transcription Regula Hohl, spelling normalized Johann Jakob Frey to John Bramhall (in copyist's hand) Date: 1635-12-17 Place: Basel
Text:
Right Reverend Father in God,
By this time I hope your Lordship is safely returned to Dublin, having as I understand by Mr Rickesis spent the greatest part of last summer in the country. If not, I have recommended this to Mr. Littell for to convey it, bgeing? Do make my humble addresses to your Lordship. If you will be pleased to assure my lord Deputy of my thanksful [sic] and hearty acknowledgments for the honour he hath done me in being mindful of his servant at this distance, and preferred me to so eminent a place in the Church of Ireland, wherein what I owe to your Lordship's good opinion and favour, I am not insensible. I beseech you, my Lord, take this assurance from your humble servant that you have none of our domestics about you whom you may command more freely, than myself; and as I am impatient of my stay in these parts, so do I beg this favour of your Lordship you will afford me but some little corner in your thoughts until I may come near your Lordship in particular. What difficulties I shall have to get my liberty from hence, your Lordship may easily foresee being not only engaged to this public by my place in the university but disctracted by many affairs of mine own by reason of our neighbours' desolation in Alsatia and he Marquisate of Baden. Therefore [I] humbly entreat your Lordship to move? my Lord Deputy that his Lordship would extend his favour yet so far as to grant me his leave of absence until I may get off here with honour and begin my journy of this transmigration with safety. Besides I am an humble suitor to my Lord Depuity that his Lorship would vouchsafe the Magistrate of this town to demand my diesngagement from hence by aletter; that being not only the mor honourable but the speediest way to procure my feedo here, which granted should make for ever his and your Lordship's servant- I am so confident of my Lord Deputy's favour and your Lordship's love and I doubt not but his Lordship and yourself my Lord will pardon this boldness of mine wherunto the necessity of so many difficultues doth oblige me. During my absence. Your Lordship will take this and other affairs of mine into your protection where I shall think them safely and well kept though by reason of my engagement here I could not dispose of them at all. This enclosed contains the state of war in these parts of tghe world which if your Lordship please to communicate with some of your friends the master of the Rolls, Master Secretary Mannering and Mr Scott. Read with it the assurance of my most humble service whereof could I give your Lordship or any of yours no greater testimony than an hearty desire of being with you, your Lordship shold assuredly believe me to be, my Lord, your Lordship's etc.
Comment: ENDNOTE: Copy of my letter to my Lord Bishop of Derry, Irland, the 17th of December 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 9 / 19 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 101-102 Microfilm pdf p. 137-139 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Oliver Fleming to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-08-9/19 Place: Zurich
Text:
Worthy Sir
I render many thanks for your letter, and deem to be excused, for not answering sooner, my absence in part besides some urgent occupations, having been [?] my silence. Your return to Basel has wrought contrary effects in me at once both sorrow and joy. Sorrow, because I perceive that by your return, your virtues, have had small hopes of obtaining such condigne? recompense of preferment as they deserve and might thereby have given you a desire to make a total transplantation of joy, because I hope the day to be made happy in your conversation, during my[?] abode, or relegation in these parts. In the meantime, I shall be ready to embrace all occasions whereby I may manifest my affection towards you. I send you here enclosed such vestments[?] as I have out of Italy which you may return me by the next ordinance [could mean some kind of postal service] and you shall do me a favour, if you will let me know the occurrences of those parts. The last week these [?] 3 French Regiments towards the Duke of [name] in all of some m/1[number?] men. The French supplies that are daily sent to Germany[?], and the return of [serbelle?] to his old quarters [?] with soon preparations that the Imperials are making [1rst advance?], doth indicate, that the Duke of Rohan is like to be assaulted on all sides, who it [?] to prepare himself against the former. I think my Lord Scudamore is already at Calais, we shall see what effect his Embassy will produce in France. I doubt not but that as you tell me many let their tongues run [?] own in censuring my [?] proceedings but the best silencing of them is to neglect them, and to let them use their Demon[?] to call liberty according to their ignorant Capriccio fuse[?] I am that that[sic] just and negligent [hence?] my Master will never do that action that may [?] to the prejudice of the orthodox church and public liberty. the certain knowledge I have of this is the greatest comfort I have in this miserable age. If I were with you, I could inform you of things that would make you rejoice at the good resolutions of his Majesty and laugh at these discoveries[?]. in the meantime, tell that [name?] that last written this enclosed abstract, that he nor no man ought to reprehend the actors of God[?] invented upon ignorant and [?] miscreations and let him consider that Grosse[r] Herren Bücher seint [?] finster zu lesen. his naming of you for an author of those untruths, does displease me greatly [?] that I believe that your discretion has been so far transported, but that these rumours as they breed ill blood amongst those who ought by all reason divine and humane, to be indissolubly united in the propagation of the true religion, and the manutention of the public liberty, so are they always pernicious to the inconsiderate authors. I pray you to remember my love and service to Mr. Battier and tell him that I have recommended his son to my Lord Feilding [Fielding?] in a good manner but if he will have a letter be sent here, too to send to his son, that he may prepare 200?? to the said Lord, I will [?][?] to send 200 him. in answer of this you may let me know his mind. I conclude by assuring you that upon all occasions I desire to approve myself.
Zurich the 4 / 14th of August 1635
Your most affectionate servant
Oliver Fleming
Comment:

Date: [unknown] Place: [unknown]
Das tut mir nachher zu Herzen gehen, das unser Herr Frey aus England bringt, der König habe sich spanisch erklärt, und mit seiner ausgeloffenen Flotte etliche spanische Schiffe gegen Dünkirchen begleitet, auch über sich genommen [?] statt wider die Staden[?] zu beschirmen. geht ihm also nicht zu herzen, dass in dem gemachten sächsischen Frieden die Oberpfalz den Bayer Fürsten, die untere aber den Spanier übergeben wird. Gott lasse uns besseren Trost von dem Herr Residenten vernehmen, dem ich hiermit untertänig will gegrüsst haben.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 21 March 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 34 Microfilm pdf p. 49 [right margin cut off]. Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized
Text:
Sir
I do not blame your magistrate who foolishly detain you. Only I wish you had sent us [cut off] who await that they would change their mind. It would pity to lose their favour for lack of an ample title. As for my lord deputy, he is ready to contribute what is in his power towards the ob[cut off] your desires myself you know to be your p[cut off] servant. I [?] by yours that mine were not com[cut off] your hands. when sooner Mr. Littellshall give the least information of any opportunity whereby I [cut off] be able to make you an expression that I am you[cut off] without either dissimulation or complements he does me an especial favour. And I shall study [cut off] give you a fair amount of it. The Church here begins by the influence of [cut off] noble Lord to lift up her head and flourish [cut off] more and more. I trust before this year be [cut off] an end I shall be able to demonstrate that [cut off] yearly [?] thereof are improved 2[cut off] [?] his coming to the sword. only his [?] England (though his absence will not be long) put a remora[hindrance] in our way for a while. I thank you for your news, I know here [?] which is not communicable unto you [cut off] better hands. So god bless us
Dublin March 21 1635
Your faithful friend[cut off] to love and [cut off] Johannes Derensis

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 5 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: Wotton, Sir Henry. "Letter to the Earl of Cork 5 December 1635." The Life and Letters of Sir Henry Wotton. 2 vols. Ed. Logan Pearsall Smith. Oxford: Clarendon press, 1966. 2:357-359. 357-358.
Text:
While the bearer, Monsieur Marcombes] was fitting himself to post out of Ireland [...], I was surprised with a fresh assault of obligations from your Lordship in divers kinds. First in making me so quickly partaker of your own joys touching the said lady's ; to whom God send many such pretty cheerful troubles, as she is like to have shortly. And I wish from a grammatical College not improperly that most of them may be of the masculine gender. [...].
My good lord, I have commended seriously [...]your spirity Robin to the master of our choristers here.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 29 March 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 15-16 Microfilm pdf p. 22-23 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini spelling and punctuation normalized William Beecher to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1636-03-29 London
Text:
Sir,
I received some time since yours of the [?] of December, with one enclosed for my Lord Chamberlain, and since that I received another of the 18 / 28 of February by Mr. Battier, with whom I have not spoken, being at the time he brought the letters in physic, and since I have not had the good happen [happiness?] to meet with him. But in neither of your letters or in that to my L[ord] Chamberlain, I can find a certain resolution whether you will accept of the charge of the Duke of Buckingham or not. Since that time there is fallen out a great disaster by the death of my young Lord Herbert my Lord Chamberlain's son, by which the alliance between my Lady Duchess and him is dissolved: but yet both my Lord Chamberlain and my Lady Duchess do continue very desirous that you should undertake the charge of the young Duke and they have now commanded me to write again unto you about it. You shall have a good entertainment to your satisfaction, you shall have the means to make yourself known and accepted both to the King, and whatsoever hath any eminence by this state, you shall have the government of a young Lord both of the great expectation, and great fortune of his [own?], by which alone you may in time expect a sufficient advancement, and if you do resolutely entertain the motion, my Lady Duchess for this letter to the Magistrates of Basel, and for his dispensation to hold the Dean of Armagh, but she would desire you to forbear it to take Ecclesiastical orders upon you, during the time you shall remain with her son. It will be to no purpose for me to move[?] for Mr. Battier or any other, in case you should refuse it, for that the Duchess and her friends will make the choice themselves. If therefore you do like of the employment, I shall be exceeding glad to be an instrument in it, or anything else that may conduce (?) to your contentment, if otherwise. I pray let me clearly and speedily understand your resolution. So wishing you all happiness I pray God to have you in his blessed keeping.
London this 29th of March 1636. [?] [?]
William Beecher
Comment:
Beecher was a "client" something for Buckingham and obtained no further advancement after Buckingham’s death. [...DNB] Imprisoned by the Lords early in the Long Parliament for having seized the papers of the 2nd earl of Warwick (Sir Robert Rich) and the 2nd Lord Brooke (Robert Greville), he was quickly released on the grounds of ‘age and infirmity’, although he may also have agreed to relinquish his clerkship, which he resigned in February 1641.
SECXONDARY Herzog, Johann Wernhard. Athenae Rauricae Sive Catalogus Professorum Academiae Basiliensis [...]. Basel: Unknown publisher, 1778.
Line reference: @100003 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 29 March 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007083 Jacob Battier / NaHu#007085 George Villiers, 2nd Duke of Buckingham / NaHu#007923 Katherine Villiers, Duchess of Buckingham / NaHu#007924 Philip Herbert, Earl of Montgomery

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 22 July 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 60 Microfilm pdf p. 77 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Lady Frances Clifford to Johann Jacob Frey Date: [year unknown, probably 1635]-07-22 Place: Chelsea
Text:
Chelsea the 22 of July
Mr. Frey,
this letter your cousin brought me from Paris is all I have received since you left England, I have desire your cousin to chide you from me, and will not trouble you more than to let you know, you can never make enemies to your friends but in your speedy return, I shall be extremely sorry[?] your mother should be in any danger of death. I hope in god she is not, [?] I am so [?] as I desire you may have that content in your journey as your obedience to her deserves, and with that truth I [smudged word] to be esteemed
Your most affectionate friend,
F[rances] Clifford
Mr. Frey I thank you for the things you sent me, this gentleman can be witness I wear them for your sake I should think [?] should be a good time for your return.
Line reference: @100060 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 22 July 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 29 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 75 Microfilm pdf p. 96 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Charles Cotterell to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-08-29 Place: Geneva
Text:
Worthy Sir
The many obligations you have laid upon me, whilst I was happy in your company, do tire me to present my service, and humble thanks for them, not a word or two since I could not be so fortunate as to meet you at London, though I were many times at your lodging, not at Paris whether I came presently after your departure, yet should I have been sufficiently satisfied if after being brought so near to you as Geneva, I had accompanied my Lord Herbert and these gentlemen to Basel to enjoy again[?] though for a short space the contentment of your good company, and to assure you how much I am, and ever will be yours, which I hope you already believe, though I have never given such proofs of it as I desired: that confidence makes [me?] [?] bolder to recommend this gentleman unto you, and with favour so ever you shall do him I esteem it done to your
most faithful friend and servant
Charles Cottrell
Geneva. 29 August 1635
In has[te]
I beseech you Sir present my Service to all your and my friends at Basel with my acknowledgment of [?] favours.
Comment: By 1652 Cotterell had moved to The Hague as steward to Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia,

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 31 July 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 70-71 Microfilm pdf p. 90-91 (right margin badly reproduced) Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized James Zouch to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-07-31 Place: Geneva
Text:
Sir,
Every since your departure from hence I have been in a perplexity of a hundred fears for the success of your journey towards Basel by reason as soon as you were gone from hence diverse companies of French soldiers which were to go for the Valtelline have been scarce? Arrived here sca? Ing here roundabout full of unhappiness. But the honest postillion arrived here two days sooner than he promised or I expected with your letter which soon relieved (received?) me with the good news it brought that the Emperor (?) could not be more ? with the success of Don gall? ????' Your lines have put me likewise in an admiration how you could in so little space of time spare this much leisure in [the] midst of visiting of your chiefest friends at Basel to think or to ?? the memory of so poor a subject as I am. You have already infinitely (?) obliged me with your former innumerable favours but your bounty bring? infinite doth almost overwhelm me not knowing how swim (?) I just desire you to be patient until I shall come to a shore where after a little respiration I may show you an expression of my willing thankfulness although it may or will not be fully satisfactory which I would entreat you to believe me that you cannot more deny my = what their intention now was for the Basel journey, as the ? or intended before but I found their appetite very coldly disposed by reason of the wars and their shortly departing from hence for Italy. I for my part was fully resolved to have been gone for Basel but that my letter has not yet come which expected from England, and then besides I am loth (?) to lose this company in my travels. For (as you know well enough) it is a melancholy thing to travel alone (facundus comes in itinere pro vehiculo est). I hope these reasons although they be but feeble will in manner make excuse for not kissing your hands at this time, and I pray believe me that although I do go further from you nevertheless my affectionate desire to serve you shall still wait at your elbow to tell you wheresoever I ? that you have one which is and will be still your affectionate friend and servant James Zouche. I pray remember my Service to Monsieur Brand your countryman Monsieur Conradus remember his humble service to you both Geneva the last of July styl. rect ? 1635
Comment: The father, Edward La Zouche, eleventh Baron Zouche (1556–1625), landowner, was born on 6 June 1556, at Harringworth, Northamptonshire, the only son of George la Zouche, tenth Baron Zouche of Harringworth (c.1526–1569), landowner, and his wife, Margaret (d. in or after 1569), daughter and coheir of William Welby of Molton, Lincolnshire. He succeeded as eleventh Lord Zouche on the death of his father on 30 June 1569. The main estates were concentrated in Northamptonshire. As a minor, Zouche became the ward of Sir William Cecil, principal secretary, who entrusted his education to John Whitgift, master of Trinity College, Cambridge. Zouche matriculated there in Easter 1570, and gained an MA in 1571.
Line reference: @100077 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 31 July 1636

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 17 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 72-73 Microfilm pdf p. 92-93 copyist's hand, right margin badly photographed) Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized James Zouch to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-08-17 Place: Geneva
Text:
Noble Sir,
I could not let pass this convenient opportunity and trusty messenger without kissing your hands by these few lines before me going into Italy. My friends and countrymen here hath for much prevailed with me, that they have made me engage myself to pass the Alps with them. So I am in extreme ?? that our affairs fall out so that we cannot enjoy your sweet company at Basel. But God willing, all the business in the world shall not hinder me [?] waiting on you the next spring as I come out of Italy. The next Monday we do intend to begin our journey. Mr. Hambleton, Mr. Campion and their company do depart from hence, this next Wednesday for Lyons. I would write to you some news but I am afraid my intelligence will come to you at the second hand- I make no question but by this time you have received letters from Mr. Battier of his safe arrival at Paris which is the author of our news, but for fear his letters should be miscarried, I will dun over the particulars. The King of England is preparing another fleet, greater than that which he hath sent out already to go out the next Spring and for the preparation of the same fleet the king hath imposed a sum of threescore thousand pounds on all his subjects but it is thought that they will hardly agree to it without a parliament. The king is much displeased with the marriage of the Duchess of Buckingham and the Lord MacDonnell His majesty hath taken both her sons the young duke and his brother from the Duchess and put them to some other place to be brought up. Me Henry Rich is gone to sea, after the fleet, The Lady Thurbicke) came to Paris disguised in man's apparel, and dieted at Curtins [?] for a week, with the other pensioners, unknown but now she hath taken a chamber and retired herself. I fear I have been over tedious to you wherefore begging pardon for the same, and desiring your to place me the catalogue of your servants and rest your faithful servant
James Touche


[vertically written in the left margin] All our army of English here present their humble services to you.
Line reference: @100078 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 17 August 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 22 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 106-107 Microfilm pdf p. 146-147 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Oliver Fleming to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-08-22 Place: Zurich
Text:
Sir
I perceive by your last unto me, that you are beginning a Greek career. I could wish you had a more numerous auditory, yet a few [indituous?] men may give a just though not a divulging applause. perhaps one day I shall step in [unlooked?] [for?]; and I promise to [?] you from the Chair to Grecan[?] or Helvetiker[?] which you will.
The French king is departed from Paris towards [Chalons?] where the [?] and [?] is assembled. which amounts in all comprised their valets and all some [number]. [?] these are great confusions in that kingdom: qui trop embrasse nul [estreinet?]. I suppose my lord Scudamore to be arrived at Paris by this time. The Empire is resolved to use all possible means for to regain the passages of the [?] line, as foreseeing that the state of Milan will run great danger, unless an Army of Germans, can be sent for its defense. Crequy hath had some small success in those parts he dares not attempt any great matter, in regard his Army doth not pass [number] foot and 300 horse. The Dukes of Savoy and Parma have not yet joined their forces with him. It seems, they stay and see what success the French are like to have in Germany, whose perhaps shortly some fatal blow will be given. The Duke of Rohan hath received some [number] Pistols[?], which will stop his Swiss[?] mouths[?], much less his discontent Army he hath under from his M[aster] if he want[s] men to raise [number] Swiss[?] more but those he hath being not paid, and [paige] ill-used. Besides, he is like to have no more. I preconceive those [Colonel?] and Captains that are now waiting [?] [number] men, to be undone considering the law of the [?] is to pay their soldiers[?] whether the kind pays or not we begin here to perceive some dangerous symptoms of the plague. I pray to inform me truly how you fare at Basel so in haste I rest.
Zurich this 22th[sic] of August 1635
your humble servant
Ol[iver] Fleming
Line reference: @100079 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 22 August 1635

Title: Letter to Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork 9 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth Archive CM 18 / 108, published in Lismore Papers 3:235-236 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized from OCR copy of Lismore papers Lady Frances Clifford to Richard Boyle, Earl of Cork Date: 1635-12-09 Place: Skipton
Text:
My Lord,
I am very glad [of] Bess' great Belly, but sorry she should not bear her first child with me, which had your Lordship at first given way to her coming over, I had now had her and her great belly with me. I was very glad when my brother told me the King had given leave for your Lordship coming over and did hope then to have the honour to have seen you, which I much desire, and am as sorry anything should hinder it. According to your Lordship's desire, I did mean to write to my Lord Deputy, and did earnestly desire my lord to join with me, to see what both our letters should have done, but my Lord showed my his letter he writ now to your lordship, wherein he is so far from that as he says he should to your lordship no service in it. I cannot tell what to think truly. But do playing wish your lordship might have your desire, and if I were with my Lord Deputy I should say so much to him, and do mean yet if I may have the least word from your Lordship to try my Lord Deputy in three or four lines if I may do you service in it. I know my lord is so civil he will return my some answer again. My Lord, I will trouble you no longer at this time, only return you many thanks for remembering Frank, and remain my Lord, your most affectionate sister and humble servant, E. Clifford

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 15 October 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 68 Microfilm pdf p. 88 (badly photographed) Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Elizabeth Giffard to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-10-15
Text:
[...] She can [illegible] Find her stronger when you come again, which she wishes may be soon [...]
Sir this day I received your letter and token. Your merry Cupid ? I will set it [in] gold and wear it for your sake: my mistress gives you thanks for hers and will do the same. [Michael] Castell tarries for these lines which makes me thus brief. We are next week for Launsbrough, which grieves my heart. I pray God bless you and send us a merry [word missing?], and so I rest your true friend and servant
October 15 1635
Eliza[beth] Giffard.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 1 September 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 69 Microfilm pdf p. 849 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Elizabeth Giffard to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-09-01 Place: Chelsea (?)
Text:
Noble Mr. Frey,
you have so much obliged me to you by our many undeserved favours that I know not which way to make you any part of requital yet I will study to def? Them if possibly I can. It seems you would not leave this kingdom till you have performed your promise. I am sorry I did not know it sooner that I might not have been so long in your debt for a ??? I sall return you by ?? my prayers to God shall every attend you wherever you are, for your good health and happy soon return into England. About the 18th day of August I received your trunk ?? of gloves ??? and ten shillings for the servants, who all with humble thanks prays God to bless you for your kind remembrance of them. My little mistress sends her love to you and prays (to) God to bless you and my Dall?? Presents her service to you and is your servant ----???? Your worthy self,. I commit you to God's worthy protection and remain your true friend and servant,
Elizabeth Giffard.
Comment: Chelsea may not be correct.
Line reference: @100085 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 1 September 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 12 July 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 68 Microfilm pdf p. 84 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Elizabeth Giffard to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-07-12
Text:
Worthy Mr. Frey,
if we had thought that the complaint of your horse's unkindess to his master should have been the last words we should have heard you speak of so long a time, we would have made a worthier construction of them than we did at that time but truly we were so far from the least thought of your ? secret and sudden departure from us that we made us to secure for which I assure you we were not a little troubled. For we did purpose to have taken our leaves of you in another manner, which uncivility we crave pardon for and desire that no occasion may hinder your soon return that we might make you some amends for our neglect, for which and all other happiness I thank you for all your favours and lastly for this ? of your ? worthy kinsman to whom for your sake I wish much happiness. I have at present nothing worth the sending far wherefore I beseech you accept this ? as remembrance of her service who will ever remain to be your friend and servant
Elizabeth Giffard

Sir, my mistress bids me tell you that now she can go alone and hopes to God you have found her stronger when you come again which she wishes may be soon

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 27 September 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 114-115 Microfilm pdf p. 161-162 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Oliver Fleming to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-09-27 Place: Zurich
Text:
Worthy Sir
I have received your last of the 23rd of September for the which, I render due thanks: after a serious consideration here to establish business of the Helvetian scholars in a necessary solid and firm manner, so that it may breed universal contentation. I find it in my judgement, a matter not easily to be effected by letters, for considering all things it requires the assidual pains of an affectionate solicitor. I hope in the dead of Winter I have the happiness to transport myself into the blessed Isle, having already demanded leave of the King, my Master, to repatriate myself for some few weeks, which when I shall obtain, I will make the said business me of my chiefest cares, which I hope to bring to a good end. For there remains only the settling it in such a manner in the universities, as that it may be durable, the greatest point being already gained by his Majesty's royal approbation, as I told you in my last letter, and I doubt not but that my Lord of Canterbury, having received an ample information, of the good it is like to produce, will second his Majesty's good intention. Concerning my journey into England, I request you will let it remain in [page] your own breast. As concerning news, I have at this time no great matter to impart unto you, only I must tell you that which I suppose you already know that this day, seven nights, we shall have a general [Byett?] at the emperor's command, where the Deputies of the Helvetian Body will be ready to hear what shall be propounded in the emperor's name. So not troubling you further I rest for ever.
Zurich this 27th of September 1635
Your affectionate Servant
Oliver Fleming
Line reference: @100088 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 27 September 1636

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 6 September 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 19 Microfilm pdf p. 27. Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized. Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford to Johann Jacob Frey. Date: 1635-09-06 Place: Dublin
Text:
Sir,
The dean of Armagh is dead, and I have given warrant for passing the seals, which will be done within a few days, that done I will send it to my Lady Dungarvan, where it shall be deposited till you come to receive it from her Ladyship that commanded that courtesy (?) for you. The rents are more but that you repair hither as soon as your other occasions will permit, which once settled the sooner we shall see you leave, the more welcome shall you be to
Your affectionate faithful friend
Strafford, Thomas W[entworth]
Dublin this 6th of September 1635
Comment:
Note in on the envelope in Johann Jacob Frey's hand: "Received from my Lord Deputy of Ireland, wherein he gives me notice of his bestowing Deanery of Armagh upon me 18 January, 1635."
SECONDARY Leslie, James B. Armagh Clergy and Parishes [...]. Dundalk: William Tempest, 1911.
Line reference: @100090 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 6 September 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 9 September 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 66-67 Microfilm pdf p. 85 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Frances (?) Clifford to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-09-14 Place: Chelsea (?)
Text:
Mr. Frey,
I am the gladdest in the world that you are safe come to your friends, which your letter gives me assurance of, I hope you find your mother in health, and that you will so much remember your friends in England as to make all that you can to return, your sudden departure is not forgot, yet forgiven if you say aside all difficulties and return to your friends who much desire it, if I may do you any service to remember your friends in Ireland of anything, pray let me but once know your mind, and I shall not fail to do it, in some of them I may challenge a great deal of power, I will not at this time trouble you, only be confident no creature is more faithful to you than your most affectionate friend F[rances] Clifford
Chelsea this 14 of September 1635

[in margin] when I am in the [?], I doubt I shall not so conveniently hear from you, which I am since [cut off] my Lord is come out of Ireland, but my Lord of Cork will not come, I wonder at it

When I am in the north, I doubt I shall not conveniently hear from you while I am ? my lord is come out of Ireland but my Lord of Cork will not ? ? come, I wonder at its ??
Comment: chelsea may not be correct.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 5 October 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 2-3. Microfilm pdf p. 5-6 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized William (?) Raylton to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-10-05 Place: London
Text:
Sir
I presume it will not be unwelcome to you (though now in the midst of your friends) to hear from those in Ireland who wish you well; and will, not[?] question find the effects of it this enclosed.
My Lord Deputy, and all our other good friends there, continue in perfect health, thanks be to God, having ended their Progress, much to their own contentments and to the Satisfaction of his Majesty here at home.
The King and the State here, have sent out units[?] into diverse inland Counties (not formerly taxed) for Levying money to set out another Fleet of Ships the next year, which will be, & those of the best, 45 in number; And I can assure you, the Service goes on with so much Alacrity and willingness in all Parts, as no[?] one place gain says it, which is much to the Comforts of all honest and good men; nay I am told, that albeit there are not yet six weeks passed since the sending out of the units[?], they are already collecting the money in Yorkshire.
Some of the Statesmen of war have been too busy and saucy upon our Coasts this last Summer, wherein I believe they do by this time see their own Indiscretion, and will learn better manners hereafter.
[next page] Our foreign News comes hither with so much uncertainty as never more, one day telling us of a great loss by the Imperialists; and another, of as much by the French at one and the same time, so that we hold it best to believe neither.
I doubt I am too troublesome to you, therefore will conclude with assuring you, that I shall be ever
Your most affectionate and humble Servant
W[iilam] Raylton
London 5. October 1635
Line reference: @100091 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 5 October 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 8 September 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 42-43 Microfilm pdf p. 58 ranscription and annotation Stefanie Heeg and Alessandro Lattanzi (spelling normalized; better text than in the 2015 Ussher Correspondence) John Ussher to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-09-08 Place: Drogheda
Text:
Worthy Sir:
Presently upon the death of the Dean of Armagh: I wrote unto my Lord Deputy (who was then newly returned from his [?] in Connaught) and put him in mind of his promise made unto you before your departure from hence. Who hath most nobly performed the same and given present order for the passing of your patent under the great seal. Your predecessor’s widow is at this time dealing with him for the rents of the quarter: ending at All-Saints next. What anywhere his Lord will give unto her, I do not yet know: but however; I should advise you to begin your entry with doing a work of mercy. for without doubt the widow and her poor children by the sottish carefulness of the late Dean are left in a most miserable condition.
I thank you for you dealing with Sirmondus touching the Manuscripts. Whatever he intended to publish, I have no reason to look for, before he hath set them out to the view of the world: But the other things I trust you will have a care of at your return hither: which I hope will be at convenient speed. Among the books which Mr. Perrin did use his History of the Waldenses ( the most whereof I thank you, you have procured for me) the Memorials of Siem[?] de Vipnaux (pastor of the churches of the Waldenses in Piemonte) are often cited the copy whereof if you could obtain, you should therein do me a good pleasure. I beseech you remember my most affectionate respects unto reverend Doctor Zwinger, and Mr. Buxtorff; whose learned letter I often read over with very great delight and contentment. Because I am uncertain, whether this letter shall ever come unto your hands
[Greek]
I write the more both negligently and briefly. And therefore commending you and your godly endeavors unto God’s blessing, I here end, and evermore
Your own most assured
Ja[mes] Armachanus
I received Mr. Moulin's little book against Image worship and the 2 small volumes of Petavius [Dionysius Petavius?] his abridgement of the Doctrine of Times: for which I heartily thank you. If there be anything since [crossed out word] forth by Petavius: or the second part of Franciscus Bosquetus' Latin history of the Church of France, be yet published: I pray you in your return bring them with you.
Drogheda Septemb. 8. 1635
Comment: This letter is mentioned in Frey's letter to Ussher of 1635-12-17 "I have received two from your grace, both dated from Drogheda, one of the 8th and the other of 17th of September last which make me so much your Grace's debtor"
Line reference: @100092 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 8 September 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 10 July 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 82-83 Microfilm pdf Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized George Garrard to Johann Jacob Frey Date:1635-07-10 Place: Hatfield
Text:
To my most worthy friend James Frey at Paris
Sir,
you did me an infinite favour in writing to me into England, I have obeyed all your commands, being then at Hatfield, where your letter found me; That noble lord and his lady give you many thanks, She will sum up all her sins against your return, and you shall be her ghostly father. The lady that most excepted against your sudden departure was the Lady Clifford whom before I left London I sought to pacify; she lives the remainder of summer at Chelsye. God send you a quick dispatch of your affairs in Germany, that you may return into England, the blessedest place of the world, by God's infinite mercies.
This shall be the prayer of your, Sir, most affectionate friend to serve you,
George Garrard
Comment: George Garrard was working for Algernon percy, Earl of Northumberland, in 1630
Line reference: @100093 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 10 July 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 4 - 14 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 85 Microfilm pdf p. 109 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized James Traill to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-08-04 Place: Geneva
Text:
Sir,
I have read your letter and do esteem myself much honoured by so kind a remembrance. If I were profitable for anything I should the more boldly desire you to make use of me as being yours by right, but you are so complete and I so empty, that there is no place for my praises, scarce for my wishes, all I can do is to testify my respects by congratulations which I do heartily for your safe arrival there amongst your friends. All here whom you are pleased to remember, do [?] and answer your love with much affection and regret, that we cannot have the contentment to [?] you; As for us we are shattered in time for our return to Paris and besides have a servant sick. Our stay here will not be much above a fortnight. Cllr Hamilton and Cllr West do kiss your hands, I shall not fail to convey your letter to Cllr Webb. We hear that Mons. Baslie[?] is returned to Paris with the Elder Rich intending a Journey into Italy. If you think me capable and worthy command me for I am sincerely your most affectionate servant Ja[mes] Traill Geneva the 4 / 14 August
Comment: On the envelope in Johann Jacob Frey's hand: Received 8. August, 1635 from Mr. Traill.
Line reference: @100094 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 4 - 14 August 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 17 September 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 44 Microfilm pdf p. 60 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Alessandro Lattanzi, spelling normalized. Print version in 2015 Ussher Correspondence is faulty James Ussher to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-09-17
Text:
Salutem in Christo Jesu
Shortly after the dispatch of my letter unto you touching the death of the Dean and the passing of your patent for that place; I received a letter from you, dated at Basel the 23rd of July last. Wherein you signify, that there is a MS. transcribed for me in the Italian tongue, containing the History of the Waldenses: which I hope will prove to be the [with a small annotation by Frey in the margin which I cannot decipher] memorials of Sieur de Vignaux; and not the same with the other Italian History of the Waldenses formerly sent unto me by Mr. Battier, which beginneth thus: (Benche in tutti I tempi sia stata grande la ingratitudine delli huomini etc.) and reaches from the beginning of the reformation until about year 1572.
Among the books [Ussher Correspondence 215 II:271 says these words are illegible. Alessandro; "in tedesco sembra proprio di leggere "Unter die Bücher, welche H.r Perrin in seiner Waldensen Histori gebraucht hat..."] which Mr. Perrin had, there was one volume wherein there were contained many Sermons of the Barbes*, an Epistle intituled (the Epistle to our Friends) and a book intituled, Sacerdotium. He had also another book, called (the Treasury and Light of Faith) and another, intituled (the Spiritual Almanac) It may be, [annotation by Frey in margin: ways which other treatises as the Antichrist p. 254 Send Perrin in french, Livres.] that good Civilian of Lions will be able to procure those, as well as he did the others: and in some requital of his kindness I will be ready to impart unto him such MSS. of my predecessor Richardus Armachany his works as are come unto my hands; especially his 29-books de Quaestionibus Armenonem, and his 7 books de Panpertate Sevratoris against the Friars. If I receive any further direction from you, the books [annotation by Frey in margin: “[…] given 2 Cousin Battier”] shall be sent unto London to Mr. Burnett: and his means conveyed to what part of France Mr. Battier shall appoint them to be transmitted. if the gentleman shall think them worthy the transcribing.
[annotation by Frey in Margin: Paris]
Sirmonus in Notis ad Apollimaris Sidmonij lib. 4. epistol 3. citat Gennadij Catalogs. Scriptom Ecclesiastic [?] [?], [crossed out words] ex codice coenoby S. Michaelis de Tumba. I hope you may get of him the differences which he hath observed in that and other MSS. from our common printed Gennadius; and the Tupplement[sic?] of the defects thereof. Idem in Notis Facundum Hermianensem, pag. 562. citat Aziti Viennensis Scriptum ad Burgundionum regem, quo Fausti ad Pantium epistolam vesellit. I suppose he means to print this himself: and therefore there is little hope to get a copy thereor from him. But I have troubled you too much already in matters of this kind: and therefore at this time will impose no further burden upon you; but expecting to see youself here with all speed convenient, I commit you to God and rest
Your own must assured
Ja[mes] Armachanus
[annotation by Frey: I have written to Lyons, whence I expect an [?] My Cousin Battier's account] Such parcels of the French Annales, as Du Chesme intends to publish in his Tomes, you need not get transcribed out of Sirmndus his [?]
Drogheda. Septemb[er] 17, 1635.
Comment: This letter is mentioned in Frey's answer to Ussher 1635-12-17 "I have received two from your grace, both dated from Drogheda, one of the 8th and the other of 17th of September last which make me so much your Grace's debtor"
Line reference: @100095 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 17 September 1635 (Ussher)
Modifications: NaHu#007083 Jacob Battier / NaBo@100082 The History of the Waldensians

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 27 April 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 31 Microfilm pdf p. 415 Transcription and annotation Stefanie Heeg and Alessandro Lattanzi, spelling normalized John Gregory to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-04-27
Text:
Sir
having vouchsafed me this great favour of your Acquaintance I am very thankful for it, and shall desire all opportunities that may [produce?] it. I have sent you a shrite as you desired. I beseech you Sir to consider with me that My MS2 Copy read[? if so then it is written as “readith”] all the first book and some part of the second and that which there is begins at Hephaestus or [?] King of Egypt but from the building of Babel and forward I have certainly recovered[or recommend] that [?] was wanting if there be anything concerning the [?] from Adam till the [?] that I would very favour to have and for more [Surolios?] if I may trouble you so far I pray Sir let me have whatsoever [?] is till you come upon the [?] of Abraham. [?] [name?], the Kings of Egypt Vulcan orus Osiris for these all I have if it be not [?] that I may borrow the MS [?] by the means that were the last way [?] if not I pray you to do the most [?] way of the wise Alsor Sir I desire to know upon what grounds [?] and [Cousrautiono?] in those excerpts distinguish Joh. Antioch from Johan. Malala. string thy arrow bolt and [?] Damage [?] and if thowough be any end of Justinian's Life that I may have it and so far further as the Author goeth. If the copy be likely to pleasure me I am bold and desire your that it may be borrowed if anywhere in the world can procure that or if not I would go so it if I were not too far all these favours I shall be accountable you will certainly acknowledge their [?] you in [?] places. In the meantime have my most hospitable thanks that you have been pleased thus far and take notice of him that is so worthy of you.
thy servant to be commanded upon all occasions!
John Gergorio
Christ Church, Oxford
Ap. 27 1635
Line reference: @100096 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 27 April 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 26 March 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 79 Microfilm pdf p. 100-101 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Richard Scott to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-03-26 Place: Dublin
Text:
Sir
that you were pleased so friendly to interpret my boldness with you when you were last at my chamber at Dublin I take for no small obligation, and it had well become me before now to have made some apology for it, I cannot say I use such boldness with everyone though towards them I so much honour as yourself I sometimes commit such errors, for which I ask pardon where I find them not well taken Sir it is a foolish way of mine with my best friends to say when I have occasion what I really think what invited me to that freedom with you to whom I was a stranger, I cannot imagine questionless a confidence I had of your worth and I was never less deceived in my life for my opinion I am and I then was as I perceive you are also, he, who governs all, guides you [cut off?] my prayers shall be for you, and where in I can otherwise serve you I will not fail to apprehend all occasions until I see you again wherein I may show myself
Your affectionate friend and servant
Richard Scott
I spoke with my Lord Deputy and he told me he had heard nothing concerning you from my Lord Clifford for what he promised to yourself you may build upon it and I am right glad of the occasion to bring you back again amongst us
Dublin the 26th of March 1635
Line reference: @100097 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 26 March 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 6 - 16 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 104-105 Microfilm pdf p. 142-144 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized. Oliver Fleming to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-08-16 [N.S] Place: Zurich
Text:
Worthy Sir
I find myself extremely beholden to you, for your confident expressions concerning your secret resolutions; and that which [?] my [?] is, the preconceived opinion of my secrecy wherein you may be [confided?] never to be defrauded[?]. If I were not a public servant to the Monarchy of Great Britain, I should with ingenuine sincerity applaud your fixed resolution: [crossed out words] which if I should [?] perform, by misconstruction, it might be thought, that my cheerful approbation did rather proceed from our gain, than from a desire to see you settled in a happy & prosperous estate [?] to your virtues. I hope shortly (but keep this to myself) to have an occasion to see you, and to express myself fully unto you both concerning public & our private affairs. Yesterday I had the honour to receive letters from my M[aster] with some important commissions which cannot yet be put in execution, many important accesses[?] my infallibly depending thereupon, being not yet come[?] to requisite[?] [?], does oblige me to use some procrastination. In the meantime be assured, that our religious and just King, has no less godly than honourable resolutions, to the comfort of all orthodox Christians[?] and to the confusion of those, which either by corruption, or out of pedantic petulance, dare to fate the action of the lord’s anointed. Those [in the?] dreams maliciously invented, and uttered[?] with the height of ingratitude (all things considered), will one day fall heavy upon the author. All those that have any inspection in the affairs of Christendom, know the indicible hurt these detestable lies have produced, almost to the loss of our spiritual and temporal liberties. this diabolical seed has produced both scandal and dissension yet a total alienation of affection amongst those who are obliged [page] by divine and humane law to be indissolubly united in the propagation of God’s truth and manutention of public liberty and that beauty of our Confederacy is made in heaven far above all earthly stipulations. The justification which you have used concerning the malicious oppression laid upon you was not necessary, for I was so confident that it was an untruth, that when the [?] Master (to whom it was written), brought me the letter, I did swear unto him, that it was impossible you should have spoken any such thing. Besides the Author has gained such ignominious fame, by his frequent stumbling upon the like though not so criminal errors[?], that small belief is added to anything that comes from him howsoever, it was necessary to make use of your sharp and sensible protestation which I have done very publicly to your honour, to the comfort of many and to his shame that [?] the cause of all this stir and pernicious rumour. I will not fail in due time and place to manifest with gratitude, the height of your devotion to his Majesty’s service.
Concerning public affairs, I have only leisure to tell you (being interrupted by an inopinate [i.e. unexpected] visit of the Venetian resident) that for certain the Duke of Crequy, has broken the peace of Italy, by besieging la Villatta, a fort seated not far from the Po. It is certain that the French armies in the low Countries do only consist of [fraction] men, which are recalled some come by land and the rest by water. I think you doubt no more of the taking of Schenkenschans [30th of July 1635- 30th of April 1636. The Siege of Schenkenschans was part of the 80 years’ war, where the Spanish successfully captured several towns from the Dutch]. Things stand not well in France. Money is scarce, and all the partisans and financiers, will advance no more money in [?] of the danger, in exacting the tally according to the [page] new edicts. the sedition in several places, is not yet extinct[?] 3 French ships, with 40 cannons a piece did meet with a small English ship in the straits [i.e. the English Channel]. The French in an arrogant manner commanded the English ship to strike [i.e. take down] sail, which being refused / refuted as not acknowledging any in [?] those the French let fly at them. The fight [lay?] till the English had but 7 men left and the French lost [?] 100. Finally, the French boarded them, whereupon some resolute fellow set fire to the powder which blew them all up together. It is said that our fleet did meet [?] fleet of 100 Hollanders which at the first call did strike side. I have given Mr. Battier's man the letter he deposed. So in haste I rest.
Your affectionate humble servant
Ol[iver] Fleming
Zurich this 16/26 of August 1635

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 24 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 26 Microfilm pdf p. 37 [microfilm hard to read]. Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized. Date: 1635-08-24 Place: Unknown
Text:
Dear Cuss [Cousin]
for my letter from Paris, and for the bearer I thank you, till your settling at Basel I stayed my land; this last week I received that your purpose, to [Battier?] but we're[or with?] all indement[ adamant?] for the good of the enclosed, undersigned to may your letter is delivered, and message to Mr. Vanli, the most of the letter is Dutch, that is, to be kept secret, the Italian only concerns me, I beg your Secretary may have employment from you, and when better settled, a more full relation of the state about you, be not sparing I beseech you of half an hour, you have spent more of your precious time on him, and he vows all his to you. / much [learning?] there is in the affairs of Germany, war[?] are constant here of[?] the gross, I shall send you nothing done on the other side the sea[?], but when it affords, it must take to make up our little/ Our fleet hath been some time in the Downs, which it hath done, should have done, or hath kept unions, I leave to your [consideration?], we have now new leaves[as in paper?] for more than 20000 for the constant supply of it, they gather it in London all ready, what the country will do, I can not say, I hope they will. be no less forward. / the Justice [?] goes on in Hampshire, where they will find forest enough; you will have good company into Ireland the next Summer, come away, the Ring [resolusd?], the [a name?] would say[?] go also; the Deputy is in the northern progress, and our King coming back his, The good news of the peace twixt the Pole and Swede, give us to [a name?] my Lord of Arundall shall soon over to fetch the Lady from the Hague [the winter Queen???], nobody dies [?] us to any purpose, Corbalt Bishop of Norwich excepted, I can not tell you that our saint our Sibbs is dead, Dr. Brownrick, a man most famous, in his place at Cambridge, elected, but whether to [shand?] we can not tell. / our Universities as you left them, consists of 4 Persons
[some for the] Points [for] both points and tricks,
[some for the] Tricks [for] neither points and tricks,
your [?] Arthur Angram[?] much cried up for a Chancellor of the [?], but how soon the change will be we can not say. / what Spoil 151 ships late gone out of Dunkirk have done among the Holland Buffs we can not yet know particularly, but great it is. / Nomore, unless better; tarwell[travel?], no mysteries[?] but suck a bous England, nor longer time to settle astays, but I must not command, these are but the wishes of your much
Endeared Cousin and friend
Jai Hodgson!
August the 24.
Must it be a month before I write again!
Line reference: @100111 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 24 August 1635
Modifications: NaVn#006981 London / NaHu#007083 Jacob Battier / NaHu#007909 Mr. Vanli

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 7 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 22-34 Microfilm pdf p. 58 Transcription and translation Alessandro Lattanzi (spelling normalized). Christoph Lüthardt to Johann Jacob Frey  Date: 1635-12-07 Place: Bern
Text:
Greetings in the name of Christ.
Most illustrious and erudite man, I received at the right time your letter, where it is indicated through whom I can safely send you the History of the Waldensians. It was in the hands of the public notaries, who subjected it to a thorough scrutiny and authenticated it by their signatures, as suggested by Mr. Spanheim to guarantee the veracity of the History. Being ignorant of the Italian language, I had nothing to do with the History, but based on what the notaries reported, I cannot, in the first place, but warn Your Excellency against what seems to me to speak to the early faith of the Reformed Church and the Waldensians. In the eighth, that is the last book, Lentulus inserted an invective speech, in which he accuses his own [parishioners] at Angrogna, and almost in general the Waldensians, of many crimes, incest, depravity, undbridled lust and licentiousness, even incestuous relationships with their own children, infanticide, and other such things. If what I have just remarked here is to be sent overseas, I leave you, most prudent man, to consider more carefully. I have no doubt about the piety of the Archbishop, even less so about his circumspection, so that I am persuaded that he will never make these things known. However, according to the proverb, writings remain, and after his death the History might possibly pass into the hands of other people, who would either accuse the Archbishop of having falsified the history if he left these facts out, or in turn make them publicly known to the detriment of the Waldensians, as they wish. But as I said, the final decision will be upon you. As for the History itself, Mr. Lentulus consented to give it under no other condition but that of making mention of his grandfather Scipio Lentulus as the author, and sending the manuscript of the History back to him. Nobody will deny that both of the conditions are fair. It is written with a rather blunted pen, thus resulting in a handwriting that is less easy to grasp at first glance, but a careful reading of the very first page suffices to lead the reader to understand it. In addition to the 10 Reichstaler that the copyist received from Your Excellency, so far I have paid a further 10 for half the paper and 5 for the public notaries, who spent eight full days in the collation and correction of the writing errors and copious quotes from the sacred writings. I have not seen the small book you make mention of in your letter. I have learned this at least from Mr. Lentulus: that this History was lost many years before the synod held in Dauphiné, but I could gain no certain information as to how it happened. Be pleased, most illustrious man, with this little letter of mine, and even in greater things, count for sure on all my zeal to serve you. Be well. The 17th December 1635 Your Excellency's most faithful Christoph Lüthardt
Line reference: @100250 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 7 December 1635
Modifications: NaHu#007002 James Ussher / NaHu#007029 Friedrich Spanheim / NaCo#009035 Waldenses / NaHu#007088 Scipio Lentulus / NaHu#007089 Julius Caesar Lentulus / NaBo@100082 The History of the Waldensians
URL:
Salutem plurimam in Christo.
Percommode tuas accepi, clarissime atque literatissime vir, quibus indicatum per quem Historiam Waldensium tuto ad te mittere possem. In manibus ea fuit publicorum notariorum, qui eam summo studio perlustrarunt subsignaruntque αὐθεντικῶϛ, quod in fidem Historiae faciendum erat, monitore Domino Spanhemio. In tota Historia ego Italicae linguae ignarus hospes fui, sed ex relatione notariorum non possum quin hic primo Tuam Excellentiam moneam, quod ad Ecclesiae Reformatae et Waldensium antiquam fidem facere mihi videtur. Subiecit Dominus Lentulus in octavo, id est postremo libro concionem invectivam.  In qua suos Angronianos  et Waldenses fere generaliter accusat multorum criminum, incestus, scortationis, indomitae libidinis et licentiae, immo et ex incestu natorum, infanticidii, et si quae sunt his similia. Quae ego quidem notavi, tibi vero homini prudentissimo diligentius considerandum relinquo an haec ad transmarinos sint mittenda. De pietate Archiepiscopi mihi non dubium, minus de eius circumspecta prudentia, sic ut mihi persuadeam ipsum haec numquam divulgaturum. Quia vero litera scripta manent, ut est in proverbio, posset post ipsius mortem Historia in aliorum manus pervenire, qui vel Dominum Archiepiscopum falsatae historiae (si omitteret) accusarent, vel eadem in fraudem Waldensium denuo publice nota facerent, prout ingenium est adversariorum. Sed, ut dixi, iudicium penes te esto. Caeterum quod Historiam ipsam attinet, non alia conditione eam concedere voluit Dominus Lentulus quam ut avi sui Scipionis Lentuli tamquam autoris in ea fiat mentio, et ut exemplar Historiae ad se mittatur.  Utrumque aequum esse nemo negabit. Descripta est obtusiori calamo, hinc character primo intuitu minus acceptus, sed ad eius cognitionem perducet lectorem vel primae paginae perlustratio. Praeter decem imperiales quos etiam scriptor a Tua Excellentia accepit, persolvi adhuc decem alios pro chartis dimidium, notariis publicis quinque,  qui in collatione et sphalmatum graphicorum,  mysticorumque pleonasticorum correctione dies integros octo consumpsere. Libellum cuius in literis mentionem facis, non vidi. Hoc saltem ex ore Domini Caesaris habeo, Synodum in Delphinatu ante bene multos annos congregatam hanc Historiam periisse, quam tamen certas ob causas non obtinuit. Tu, vir clarissime, hanc meam epistellam  bene consule, et in maioribus etiam omnia officia a me indubitato exspecta et vale.
	Dabam XVII Decembris MDCXXXV
Tuae Excellentiae officiosissimus
Christophorus Lüthartus
