Title: Letter to James Ussher 25 June 1635
Bibliographical reference: Published in Ussher Correspondence II:664-665 and Elrington XVI Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini from OCR of Elrington from archive.org spelling normalized Johann Jacob Frey to James Ussher Date: 1635-06-25 Place: Paris
Text:
Most Rev. Father in God,
To give your grace an account as I ought of your commands, would require a longer stay here, than the expostulations of my friends, and the ill news of my mother's sickness could at this time permit. Only I must let you see that whilst I have been here, I have not been altogether idle in your grace's service; and what by reason of my sudden departure from hence, I could not perform myself, shall be attended and followed by my kinsman, Mr. Battier, who is now gone for England with one of my lord of Warwick's sons, and returns hither again within these two months, as desirous as myself to serve your grace in all things.
To this end I have left with him the copies of your grace's letters, and engaged Jesuit Sirmond, by a solemn promise, to assist him. Sirmond is of that disposition, that he will do more for a stranger, than for one of his familiar friends; yet where he hath a design to print any thing that he hath in his hands, nobody is able to get it from him.
He purposes to set forth what he can get of Hincmarus, and therefore unwilling to part with any thing he hath of him ; only what Vossius got from hence, I am promised a copy of it by that time my cousin comes back again, which shall be sent to your grace, with the printed books that could be found here, whereof this is the note. Prudentius Tricassinus is in Thuani bibliotheca; which, with the rest, shall be seen there by my cousin at his return, if Monsieur Camusate do not send it before from Troyes, in Champagne, where he lives. Sirmondus tells me that one of their society in Flanders is about printing the lesser Greek Fathers together; amongst which is Ignatius, whereof he hath what could be had for him here. And Monsieur du Chesne is busy in setting forth the antiquities of France in Latin, where many of those pieces will be printed, your grace desires. A new edition of the General councils is finished here, but hath nothing else but Binius printed a little better. Theodoret is half finished, with Sirmondus his notes ; Cyril is a printing, and the great work of the Bible wants nothing but Joshua and the Judges in Syriac and Arabic, which is now a-doing, the price will be between forty and fifty pounds.
To-morrow, God willing, I leave Paris, and take my way by Lyons and Geneva ; whence after some two days' stay, I go immediately to Basel, being called upon extremely for my delay. From thence I will take leisure to write to your grace at large. Now I humbly beg pardon for my haste, recommending your grace to God's safest protection, and continuing,
My Lord, your Grace's most humble,
And most faithful servant,
J[ames]. Frey
Paris, 25 of June, 1635.
I have sent your grace a little treatise, De imaginibus, made by Monsieur Du Moulins at Sedan, and have directed it to Mr. Burnett.
Comment:
SECONDARY Ussher, James. The Correspondence of James Ussher, 1600-1856. Ed. Elizabethanne Boran. 3 vols. Dublin: Irish Manuscript Commission, 2015.
O'Sullivan, William. "Ussher As A Collector Of Manuscripts." Hermathena 88 (November 1956): 34-58.
O'Sullivan says: Before 1628, when intercourse with France was tem porarily stopped because of Buckingham's abortive attempt to relieve La Rochelle, the great French Jesuit scholar and ecclesiastical historian, Jacques Sirmond, knowing that Ussher was working on the medieval heretic, Gottschalk, sent him transcripts of two manuscript confessions of Gottschalk from the Abbey of Corbie.55 These are not now in our library because Ussher, in turn, sent them to Vossius in 1630, just the year before his own book was published in Dublin.56 When communications were restored Ussher was again busily ordering transcripts to be made in Paris, Jas. Frey, a French Protestant naturalised in Ireland, wrote to him from Paris, 25 June, 1635 : ' I have not been altogether idle in your grace's service and what by reason of my sudden departure from hence, I could not perform myself, shall be attended and followed by my kinsman, Mr. Battier ... To this end I have left with him copies of your grace's letters and engaged Jesuit Sirmond by a solemn promise to assist him. Sirmond is of that disposition that he will do more for a stranger, than

Title: Letter to Philip Herbert, Earl of Pembroke 17 October 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 158 Microfilm pdf p. 225 [draft? in copyist's hand, with date added in Frey's hand] Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Johann Jacob Frey to Philip Herbert, Earl of Pembroke Date: 1635-10-17 Place: Basel
Text:
Right honourable, my most honoured Lord,
Amongst many your Lordship's unprofitable servants, I have had the honour to be known of you not by any service they could do you yet but by such favours you bestowed upon them, I must needs account myself one the chiefest having neither merit to deserve what I ought your Lordship at my being in England; nor power to acknowledge now what obligations I received from you since which I confess had not ?? exceeded my beliefs, than it now doeth my best expressions of thanks; had not your William Beecher of late given me assurance thereof in his letter and so obliged me to this return, which I humbly desire may be thought as void of presumption as I wish it full of gratitude. The honour your Lordship doth me in thinking me capable of so great a charge exceeds all my merits so far that were I at liberty as I am now bound to Basel against my will I durst not undertake it; neither do I know how my resolution of being a churchman hereafter would please your Lordship if I were able otherwise to undergo it.
I have written at large to Sir William Beecher who will present your Lordship the willingness of my service with a desire to be disengaged here, if I might be your Lordship's altogether.
My Lord Herbert and Mr Philip made so short a stay in this town when they passed through Switzerland that I could not have time enough to appear sufficiently their servant: neither could the longest time confirm the extent of my desire that being infinite as well as my ambition is to be for ever, my Lord, your Lordship's servant etc.
Line reference: @100031 Letter to Philip Herbert 17 October 1635

Title: Letter to Elizabeth, Lady Dungarvan 17 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 152-153 Microfilm pdf p. 216 Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl spelling normalized Johann Jakob Frey to Lady Dungarvan [says Staehelin 1964 and it seems plausible] Date: 1635-12-17. Place: Basel
Text:
Madame,
What I fear I had to be forgotten of your Ladyship my want of power to deserve the favour of your thoughts multiplied every day more and more: until your Ladyship's letter from Lismore of the 12th of June last, gave me assurance again, that your Ladyship continues still mindful of your servants, though they be of those that confess themselves unprofitable. Which part of generosity you have always used with such an excess towards me that I must be ashamed of my poverty when I consider your Ladyship's continual obligations and of my unworthiness to receive them. This last favour of your Ladyship's by which I am now honoured from my Lord Deputy in the Church of Ireland, were enough to challenge all possibility of power, that ever while I breathe might give me hopes to deserve it: and being formerly so many ways yours, I cannot flatter myself with new acquisitions of merit unless they proceed from the abundance of your Ladyship whether in justice they ought to return. At this distance I can have no hopes of it at all, I therefore humbly entreat your Ladyship to have patience with your debtor, till he come out of Egypt into the land of promise, which will be a mere impossibility for me to think on, unless I may have a year's time or more to free myself by degrees, I convert my estate into money, (a thing in these times of want most difficult.) Besides for the procuring of my disengagement with the public, where, (as your Ladyship knows) I have a professor's place in the University, nothing but my Lord Deputy's letter to the Magistrate, I my Lord Primate's to the University, can be available which favours though I confess myself unworthy of, yet being to speak to your Ladyship (which doeth not consider my merit, but her own goodness to oblige freely) I am thus bold, to beg this double favour for to attain the service I owe now to God in his churches shall consist in my devotion to you I [?]. But whilst I am forced to continue absent from my charge in Ireland I beg both of my Lord Deputy and my Lord Primate, that my instalment may be done by a proxy, and a dispensation granted for my absence. I have heretofore heard of my Lordship Primate, that this Deanery has a free and temporal estate, not binding to a local residence and therefore imagine, your Ladyship will easily obtain the letter, the greater having been granted at the entreaty. [next page] Pardon I beseech you Madame, this presumption of mine, which if it abuse of your Ladyship's goodness, commits the fault of an extreme desire to take hold of this opportunity to become totally and perpetually yours. What news this place affords my Lord hath in his and his Ladyship's question being answered in this, what obligations I humbly entreat from you both, and continue whilst I live, Madam, Basel 17. Dec. 1635 1635 your Ladyship's servant
Line reference: @100032 Letter to Elizabeth, Lady Dungarvan 17 December 1635
Modifications: NaHu#007002 James Ussher / NaHu#007040 Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford

Title: Letter to James Ussher 17 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 162 Microfilm pdf p. xxx (not in ssher Correspondence) Transcription and translation Regula Hohl Trillini Johann Jacob Frey to James Ussher Date: 1635-12-17 Place: [Basel]
Text: I have received two from your grace, both dated from Drogheda, one of the 8th and the other of 17th of September last which make me so much your Grace's debtor, over and above those obligations which I ought (owed?) you before, that I am like to break, if payment were to be made at this instant. God knows my heart and how much it is devoted to your Grace's service; my best return of thanks is my sincerest desire I have to be worthy of the honour which your Grace hath done in this preferment whereby I am become a member of the church I long to serve in whilst it continues the glory with ? your Grace's person. What difficulties I shall have t free myself here your grace may easily foresee, being on only engaged to the public in my place at the university but distracted (by) so many affairs of mine come by reason of the neighbour's desolation in Alsatia and the Marquisate of Baden; wherefore I must hubly beseech your grace to extend yet your favour so far as to grant me your dispensation for my absence, until I may get off here with honour and begin my journey of transplanting myself with safety. I do solicit the same addition of favour of my Lord Deputy, and of his Lordship besides the licence of being absent. A letter to our magistrate in Latin wherein he ma demand my freedom in such terms as your Grace may be please to inform and persuade his lordship. The necessity of my stay here makes me thus bold, which I humbly beg to be pardoned of your Grace and excused, where it shall be necessary. Concerning my predecessor's widow I am very well contented to follow your Grace's good counsel and because Mr. Littell, my Lord Deputy's secretary gave me notice of a petition which the widow preferred to my Lord Deputy whose ... upon it was that she should apply herself to me
Line reference: @100033 Letter to James Ussher 17 December 1635

Title: Recommendation for Johann Heinrich Hummel 24 August 1635
Bibliographical reference: Gataker, Thomas.  "[Testimonial for Johann Heinrich Hummel 24 August 1635]." Staatsarchiv Bern. Kirchenwesen, Bd. 63, Nr. 48: Zeugnis Gatackers für Hummel. Quoted in: C. Erni, ed. "Histori des Lebens Johannis Heinrici Hummelii : eine Autobiographie aus dem 17. Jahrhundert." Berner Zeitschrift für Geschichte und Heimatkunde 12 (1950): 24-57, esp. 32-33. Translation Regula Hohl Trillini.
Text:
Thomas Gataker, unworthy pastor of the parish of Rotherhithe onf the Thames near London greets the reader. It is the duty of a Christian man to testify in truth and charity and Christian reason demands that we give well-deserving brethren our praise where the occasion is apt [saltern] and attestation to repay an owned favour (?). I therefore Johann Heinrich Hummel of Berne, who was recommended to me by the Reverend Mr. Wilhelm Thilen (?), de meliore nota and who with my son-in-law, the minister Mr. Francis Taylor (cum aedes propriae a peregrinis aliis jam essent occupatae) procurante me divertentem, noverim, dum in partibus istis ageret pie, probe studioseque admodum tempus suum transegisse rei literariae, Theologiae cumprimis operam strenue dedisse, ejusque rei gratiâ tum Academias nostras adiisse; tum et hominum eruditorum istic degentium, quorum collationibus proficere posset, limina sedulo trivisse, omni denique ope pro viribus adnisum, quo pietate veritatisque scientiâ auctior ad suos denuo reverteretur.
Haec aliis itidem quorum id interesse poterit scripto meo isto nota fieri pervelim, quod et spem mihi faciunt fidemque (ita opto voveoque) ne utinam inanem fore dum et mores hominis compositos et ardorem pietatis et veritatis eruendae sitim inexplebilis operamque inde fessam intueor fore, ut temporis progressu Deo opt. max. coeptis annuente conatusque studiosos benedictione suâ provehente vas in domo ipsius quod Ecclesia est perquam commodum ad gloriam ejusdem promovendam animarumque salutem procnrandam sit féliciter evasurus.
And this I testify with my own hand (which understandably trembles a little) and with my mind (which is not shaky) suffragante and solemnly confirm. Written at Rotherhithe August 24, in the year of salvation in lucem editae 1635.
Line reference: @100261 Testimonial for Johann Heinrich Hummel 24 August 1635
Modifications: NaHu#007937 Johann Heinrich Hummel / NaHu#007938 Francis Taylor
URL: Thomas Gatakerus, Ecclesiae Rotherhithiensis ad Thamesis ripam prope Londonium Anglorum sitae Pastor indignus, Lecturis Salutem. Hominis Christiani officium est testimonium reddere veritati charitatisque Christianae ratio exigit, ut fratribus bene meritis, ubi occasio justa oblata fuerit, appobatione saltern attestationeque nostra decus debitum rependamus. Qum itaque Joannem Henricum Hummelium Bernensem a reverendo viro D. Wilhelmo Thileno, de meliore nota mihi commendatum et apud generum meum D. Fr. Tailerum verbi divini Ministerum (cum aedes propriae a peregrinis aliis jam essent occupatae) procurante me divertentem, noverim, dum in partibus istis ageret pie, probe studioseque admodum tempus suum transegisse rei literariae, Theologiae cumprimis operam strenue dedisse, ejusque rei gratiâ tum Academias nostras adiisse; tum et hominum eruditorum istic degentium, quorum collationibus proficere posset, limina sedulo trivisse, omni denique ope pro viribus adnisum, quo pietate veritatisque scientiâ auctior ad suos denuo reverteretur. Haec aliis itidem quorum id interesse poterit scripto meo isto nota fieri pervelim, quod et spem mihi faciunt fidemque (ita opto voveoque) ne utinam inanem fore dum et mores hominis compositos et ardorem pietatis et veritatis eruendae sitim inexplebilis operamque inde fessam intueor fore, ut temporis progressu Deo opt. max. coeptis annuente conatusque studiosos benedictione suâ provehente vas in domo ipsius quod Ecclesia est perquam commodum ad gloriam ejusdem promovendam animarumque salutem procnrandam sit féliciter evasurus. Atque haec ego sub manu propria (tremula licet) mente (nec eà trepida) suffragante testor spondeoque. Dedi Rotherhithii, Augusti XXIV, Anno salutis in lucem editae MDCXXXV.»

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 13 January 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 50 Microfilm pdf p. 66 Transcription Stefanie Heeg, spelling normalized Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1635-01-13. Place:
Text:
Honest Mr. Frey
Though I have scarce a minute's time [?] me to write unto you yet cannot I chose but [?] that in [assuring?] you that I esteem and [?] you as much as one friend can do another two days here I will write unto you at large nor I will only desire you that the bonds which Perkins had from my Lord Ranelagh [?] and me may be delivered to Mr. Robotham and you will likewise deliver unto him the letter of Attorney[?] I made you at Ripton[?]
[left margin, very scribbled] when you went up to London. if there made[?] any discharge from Mr. [Stew??] for the receipt of those money I had in France I pray procure it and send it over unto me I prawned my gold chain for twenty pounds, Arthur Trever[?] can tell where it is, I pray let Perkins inquire of him where it lies and let him redeem it and send it over with all speed, I will repay the money unto him at latest with the other 15 pounds he laid out for this in Lastness [?]
Lysmore this 13. Jan. 1635
Your assured faithful friend
Dungarvan

Honest Mr. Frey,
I must even confess myself obliged unto you, not only for the affection you have ever showed me but for the care also which you have always had to maintain my credit both abroad and at home, the pains which have taken since your last coming to London is not little proof of it from nobody but Mr. John James could have stopped so many creditors' mouths with so small sums, but herein you showed yourself as well a perfect orator as a faithful friend for except you had gone a degree beyond the perfection of ? on that trade you had never been able to prevail with those inexorable villains. Lismore this 12th of June 1635
Mr. Frey
I am glad to have such an occasion as now presents itself to [?] you to this half of the world again for the dean is dead whose place my lord Deputy gave you the reversion of, and your presence is shortly expected here to take possession of it, my Lord Deputy sent to me to give you notice of it and the patent is to be drawn, which he will send me to keep because he says he granted it at my entreaty, and I shall keep it faithfully for you till I deliver it into your own hands which I wish may be very seekingly. I give you this notice beforehand that you may prepare yourself for a sudden return and as soon as I can procure my Lord Deputy's letter to you I will send it, for you will need something to show your Continent for their satisfaction, because of your short stay among them. I must now thank you for the fine present you sent me from Paris. as soon as I come to Dublin I will present your tokens to the ladies of the Castle. My Lord Clifton was gone from me into England before they came, so that I must send hers after her.
[in margin] I am yet tied to Ireland myself and if you make any hast you will find me where you left me and [partially folded letter?] the same in the [?] of my good wishes to you as
Your most affectionate friend and servant Dungarvan
Line reference: @100036 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 12 June 1635
Modifications: NaHu#007040 Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 24 November 1635
Bibliographical reference: Wotton, Sir Henry. "Letter to the Earl of Cork 24 November 1635." The Life and Letters of Sir Henry Wotton. 2 vols. Ed. Logan Pearsall Smith. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1966. 2:355-357. 355-356.
Text: Yes I have had your Lordship's commands in my meditations, touching your two designed travellers [Cork's sons Francis (?) and Roger]; wherein I will deliver my opinion with Kentish freedom [...] that I think [it] is verily your good fortune to have missed Monsieur Bat[t]ier (who, I hear, besides his present engagement abroad is more engaged if he were nearer a wife); in whose room I shall humbly present unto your Lordship one (as I conceive after a careful and strict examination of all circumstances) born for your purpose, namely this bearer, Monsieur Marcombes. [...]. He is by birth a Frenchman, native of Auvergne, but seven years resident in Geneva, very sound in religion [...] furnished with good literature and languages, especially with Italian. [...] He seemeth neither of a lumpish nor of a light composition, but of a well-fixed mean. [...] I believe my Lord Dungarvan will afford him his good word [...].

Title: Celebratory poem on the birth of Johann Jacob Frey III
Bibliographical reference: [normalized spelling] e-rara
Text: Sing, quoth the royal prophet David, a hymn to God Domino hymnum, you that have experienced his goodness; make famous the memory of his holiness. [...] ESTHER OSTEIN and CATHARINA GÜNTZER, have experienced his [...] when they were extremely sad and afflictted because of the bitter death of their son and husband; now God has made them happy with the little son and grandson who bears his father's name. [...] Johann Jacob Frey, sings in Heaven glory to the Highest [...].

Title: Letter to Oliver Fleming 6 / 16 July 1636 (and draft)
Bibliographical reference: Basel, UB, UBH Frey-Gryn Mscr I 23:Bl.183-185 Microfilm p. 276 Letter to N.N. 6 / 16 July 1636. Basel, [6./16.] Juli 1636 1 Bl.; 31 cm
Text:
Sir,
for want of better counsel which hitherto I expected from you upon my letter, but in vain, I was forced to embrace the opportunities which this bearer Mr Müller offered me by chance to save both our credits. I heard him say the last week that his affairs would cause him to make a journey to Zurich where having use of some monies he would gladly remit thither what he had too much this fair at Strasbourg, wherupon I went to the merchant that lent us the 200 dollars and will sty no longer for the payment; entreated him to accept of the payment that Mr Müller would make him at Strasbourg; he made some difficulties at first by reason of the time being past, but at last accepting of it gave me occasion to tell Mr. Müller I would let him have 208 [...] at Zurich if he would undertake for the same sum at Strasbourg. He passed his word to the merchant and gave him satisfaction upon this my bill of exchange which I have given him directed to you entreating you by all means to see it paid upon sight that neither your nor my credit suffer. And withall believe this truth, had it been in my power to study a better way to give the merchant satisfaction, I would have done it and assured you I am constantly, Sir,
your most affectionate and humble servant,
Ja[mes] Frey

NOTE ON THE BACK:
Copy of my letter to Mr. Fleming 6 July 1636 [...] German note
Line reference: @100188 Letter to Oliver Fleming 6 / 16 July 1636

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 19 February 1636
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth collection
Text: [SUMMARY Assures the Earl that his young masters have always been true observers of his lordship's mandates. Mr Francis in endued with the excellentest nature that was created in man. He is grown in tallness and straight, but comely of body; a lover of pious books and of the Scriptures. He loves learning, but his memory is much inferior to Mr Robert's. His greatest delight is in hunting and horsemanship, from which Mr Robert often dissuades him, and exhorts him to learning in his youth. He is wise and discreet, learned and devout, and it is not such devotion as is accustomed in children, but with all sincerity he honors God, and prefers him in all his actions. He is of a fair amiable countenance, is gorwn much and very healthful. His delight is in learning and he takes no pleasure in playing with boys. This quarter he learned to play on music and to sing. It is a happiness to see how lovingly the two brothers live together, so that were never yet two ill words passed between them; especially when the younger exceeds the elder in some qualities. Mr Vice Provost protests that he never saw sweeter or civiler gentlemen in the College.]
Line reference: @100452 Letter to the Earl of Cork 19 February 1636

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 16 March 1636
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth collection
Text:
tbe
[thought that the University of Oxford did very well merit some digression out of their way to view it. Saw there the library, the most famous Colleges and the fairest churches. At Eton sent for Mr Francis and Mr Robert, who supped and lay with their brothers. At London found that Mr Perkins had finished the young Lord's clothes, and was very glad they were so fine; for when walking in St James's Park, Lord Goring and his son the Colonel, came up and presented them to kiss the Queen's hands. Begs their allowance may be paid to Mr Chamberlain of London, who will send after them abroad. Have been often with Sir Harry Wotton, who is now in London. Will write again from France. Intend to pass through Normandy as Picardy is full of soldiers.]
Line reference: @100373 Letter to the Earl of Cork 16 March 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007933 W. Perkins / NaHu#007964 Sir Henry Wotton / NaHu#007967 George Goring, Lord Goring

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork 7 June 1636
Bibliographical reference: Chatsworth collection
Text:
tbe
Received his lordship's letter in 6 days from Dublin. All that come from him are endued with a strange spirit of diligence. Was thirsty to hear from Mr Marcombes how the two noble brothers did suit with a foreign air; and received a letter from him of 12 April. The best is, they have a wise and loving father, which is a sure merit. Received from Lady Goring a letter desiring to see the two young Etonians her brothers, for the Whitsuntide Vacation; and so sent them to her at Lewes, with the Captain of the School, a well-learned and well-tempered boy. She will see Frank in better health, and Robin will entertain her with his pretty conceptions a great deal more smoothly than he was wont.
Line reference: @100376 Letter to the Earl of Cork 7 June 1636

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 15 October 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 27 Microfilm pdf p. 39. Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl, spelling normalized. James Hodgson to Johann Jacob Frey.
Text:
Dear Cuss! [short for Cousin]
your second I [?], this congratulates you according to your common vote, when all danger will not deter you at home, some pleasing profits must allure you abroad from Ireland we hear also the Deputy's my Lord Dungarvan with currents as you enjoyed me. Here hath been a fortnight's noise of the prince electors coming over, and of his stay, now your greatest part conclude his coming, lodgings are provided for him at Hampton Court, if he comes suddenly, if he stays till the King comes to London, he has the Princes as Whitehall, and all the children will be at Wallingford house, because your [name?] use St. James, she looks not till toward Candeling. Our ship money is gathering on cheerfully, since our fleet hath done such good [?], Captain Stradling one of your 6 ships now left abroad, writes that he late made the Admiral of France and another with him, strike; our customs in many particulars with all justness will soon be raised, being the lowest in Christendom, Dr Wren? Bishop of Hereford shall be Bishop of Norwich, I must tell you he is likely to hold up high, St. David's succeeds him, we have nothing but Romish relations of all things abroad, I beseech you enlarge yourself, and in requital I will be short, since our so little merit; they are putting in a new bill in the star chamber against my Lordship Lincolns, it seems they will not give up the first. We have good store of Monopolies every day, which certainly will be very beneficial for your Kingdom, in their laudable intention, there is a precept came yesterday unto London to enquire the number, quality of all strangers, it says because of the fear the plague, but I understand the plague in trade, by which they undermine our natives[?] [in margin] no more but my desire to [serve?] you hear if ought I may, and that you continue me in the list of your friends? Lovers?
James Hodgson
Line reference: @100070 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 15 October 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007055 Richard Boyle, Earl of Dungarvan / NaHu#007040 Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford / NaHu#007920 Charles I

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 30 April 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 4 Microfilm pdf p. 8. Transcription and annotation Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling and punctuation normalized. George Carr to Johann Jacob Frey
Text:
Sir
According to your own intimation to my Lord, you here receive his Lordship's enclosed to the Senate of Basel, for obtaining your Licence of Absence thence and I wish your coming may be speedy, as I hope it will be prosperous. [Indeed?], After my Lord’s love remembered to you, I have it in command to acquaint you that his Lordship expects your being here within six months after this comes to your hands. Otherwise, your lengthy absence would become irremediably prejudicial to you in your Deanery through lapse of time.
I have sent you the enclosed letter sealed with a flying seal to [the?] intent yourself may peruse it, and at after only (as you well know) [?] the post and all’s firm. I purposely omitted to subscribe it but left that to yourself best acquainted with titles therein to be given. Herewith you also receive my Lord of Derry's [i.e. John Bramhall] to you. They all had commission to you but your Mr. Littell (who heartily commends him to you) mentioned of a former letter sent to you by London which was miscarried, so I thought safest to stay these till by some convenience [?] might send them hence immediately with more safety to you. And if I have done amiss therein, do beseech your pardon. I shall not be further troublesome to you at this time hoping shortly to make [presentation?] of my respects to yourself here in Person. So I rest.
Dublin this last of April 1636.
Your very affectionate friend and humble Servant.
George Carr
Line reference: @100073 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 30 April 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007006 Thomas Littell / NaHu#007087 John Bramhall

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 12 January 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 94 Microfilm pdf p. 124-125 Transcription and translation Regula Hohl Trillini Lucas Burckhardt to Johann Jacob Frey Date: 1636-01-12 Place: Geneva
Text:
The honours and favours which I received here through your courtesy oblige me to keep them in particular remembrance, which is what I am doing at this moment by writing to you in a language which they assure me you are a master of ???[...] when I make mistakes please be so gracious as to correct them.
I rejoice in your domestic happiness and wish you the happiest of fortunes in it [...]. I beg your Excellency to forgive me for having been so bold as to incommode you in your great affairs with my little one.
I remain humbly at your orders and kiss your hands
Your servant [...]
I sent your Excellency an envelope which Mr. Giovanni Battista Coiro gave me but this has not yet been answered.
Comment: Was he in England??
Line reference: @100075 Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 12 January 1636
URL:
Gli onori e favori quali ricevei quà dalla sua cortesia m'obbligano a tenerne memoria particolare, ciò che io faccio al presente a scriverli in una lingua di cui m'assicurano che ? ne pu?o esser maestra à ? che quand'io farò errori per sua cortesia li corregga. Rallegrandomi dunque del suo felice casamento ed augurandoli felicissimi successi in quello, come ancora questo già entrato anno di esserli ottimo ed secondo li suoi desideri con molti altri seguenti. Non è necessario aggiunger neue alcune di Lamagna? Ar altri luoghi, poiche VS senza dubbio è assicurata assai die quelle tuttavia ciò si può far un'altra volta quando VS si piaccia in esse. Io prego VS di scusarmi avendo preso ardire d'incomodarla ne suoi affari grandi con questa mia. Mentre resto affettuosamente ai sui comandi ed li bacio le mani.
Geneva Gennaio 1636. Servo M. Luca Burckhardt PS Io mandai a Vostra Signoria ? un plico che mi diede il Sig. Gio,. Battista Coiro mà non ha ancora risposta.

Title: Letter to Thomas Wentworth 19 December 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 27 Microfilm pdf p. 39. Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl, spelling normalized. Theodor Zwinger to Thomas Strafford.
Text:
Grace and peace from our Lord Jesus Christ. Most illustrious Lord Deputy,
If that which our mortal hearts conceive corresponded to (your?) events, Mr. Johann Jacob Frey, Professor of Greek, would still be dwelling in the bosom of our University, in the sight of his sad mother [...].
Comment: The mournful conclusion to the negotations between Basel and Ireland over the career of Johann Jacob Frey.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Frey 20 December 1635
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 36 Microfilm pdf p. 51. Transcription Stefanie Heeg and Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized. John Bramhall to Johann Jacob Frey. Date: 1635-12-20 Place: Dungannon
Text:
Sir
I understand from my very good friend Mr. Raylton of a second letter of yours whencewithal you were pleased to honour me. Though it was not my happiness that it should come to my hands I fear the messenger that brought it hath sustained more of whose safety his friends despair after so long expectation. When I was in Carnagh waiting upon my land I acquainted him that the Deanery of Armagh was likely [?] due to fall [boyd?], and his [promise?] to you. And accordingly it happened (though after my return) within a fortnight. And [beinly?] if you had been here I suppose you would readily have listened to an exchange proposed by the Dean of Clogher of his Deanery for yours, which upon exchange he was ready to [?] at 400f a year a [bone?] the [?]. The reason of his desire was some heafs[sheep] which he much he much at his first [?] at an unde[?] which by exchange would be avoided. So much I [desire] Mr. Littell long [?] [?] my absence to [smudged writing] unto you And now I have done. I have been at Dublin this term as busy as ever you see me and much more And now I am going to Derry only to [hope?] Christmas that my [reiglings?] should not complain of me in that respect And then I must [?] instantly. In my way I have gained the [smudged word] of all my lead [?] Tenants which will be the bettering of his [reclaim?] 1200f a year In my [?] back I hope to do the like for Clogher[smudged]. I thank god and my land [?] we gain [smudged word] daily other news we have none but that my land [name?] was censured[?] the other day at [smudged word] want to life[?] his captain's place his [smudged word] of the winner[?] his lie[?]: the lost may [smudged word] [smudged word] [in margin] but hardly the former. Your old friend Mrs. Hay is a widow long since. I told her I would [seal?] my letter with her name. The sooner you come the more welcome to [name?] who shall [?] study to express himself.
Dungannon December 20th 1635
Your faithful friend and servant Johannes Derensis

Title: Letter to Christoph Lüthardt 4 February 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 178 Microfilm pdf p. Transcription and translation Alessandro Lattanzi Johann Jacob Frey to Christoph Lüthardt Date: 1636-02-04 Place: Basel
Text: You must have thought me very ungrateful, most illustrious and revered Sir, since I allowed so many weeks to pass before responding to your very kind letter written on the 17th December, and without even giving you any token of gratitude for so many favours you have obliged me with. But overwhelmed thus far with domestic duties, I beg your pardon: who, if late, confesses in earnest that he owes Your Reverence more than he is able to pay, cannot think of any repayment other than that coming from heaven. I did read thoroughly the manuscript of the History, which beats the vices of the Waldensians, but not their faith; thus, I do not see what damage may arise from publishing the History in its present form. In addition, the Archbishop of Armagh asks for these writings for no other purpose than this, that a man no less distinguished for his excellence in discernment than for his learning and devotion may thus complete a work on the ecclesiastical succession, based on the authority of respectable historical writers, which he had started writing many years earlier. Should he draw anything out from this to bridge the gap concerning the Waldensians, he will doubtless avoid mentioning the name of the author, as it is fair, in relation to the consideration due to the History, and will gladly give a copy of his book as a minimum token of gratitude. As for the rest, I want Your Reverence to be firmly persuaded that there is nothing I wish more than to acknowledge the benefits received by properly reciprocating benefits. As opportunity offers, put me to the test, and be well. Basel, the 4th February 1636 Your Reverence’s most faithful, etc.
Comment: Note in J. J. Frey’s hand, fol. 178v: "A copie of my letter to D Luthard at Berne in answer of his letter received ye XXth of December 1635." The letter discusses a copy of Scipio Lentulus' Historia made for the Archbishop of Armagh, and the concerns previously raised about the book's depiction of the Waldensians.See also: letters of 17 Dec. 1635 and 20 Sept. 1635.
Line reference: @100069 Letter to Christoph Lüthard 4 February 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007002 James Ussher / NaBo@100082 The History of the Waldensians
URL:
Ὑγιαίνειν καὶ εὖ πράττειν
Ingratum me dixeris, reverende et clarissime vir, qui tot iam septimanas praeterfluere passus sum priusquam ad humanissimas tuas XVII Decembris exaratas literas responsi aliquid, vel ullam gratitudinis tesseram darem tibi tot me officiorum generibus devincienti. At veniam peto oeconomicis negotiis hactenus oppressus: qui serio, licet sero, profitetur se plus quam sit solvendo Reverentiae Tuae debere, nec aliam meditari potest ἀνταπόδοσιν quam quae coelitus proficiscatur. Perlegi librum Historiae, qui vitia Waldensium perstringit, at non fidem; unde non video quid damni oriatur ex ipsamet (ut nunc scripta est) Historiae editione. Praeterea non alio fine petit Archiepiscopus Armachanus scripta haec, quam ut exinde opus (quod ante aliquot annos inchoaverat) de successione Ecclesiae, ex fide dignis historicis, absolvat vir non minus prudentia quam eruditione et pietate excellentissimus. Si quid exinde ad supplendum istum intervallum de Waldensibus hauriat, procul dubio authoris nomen (ut par est) ad fidem Historiae vitabit, et quod minimum erit gratitudinis τεκμήριον scripti exemplum dabit ex animo. Quod suprest Reverentiam Tuam certo persuasam volo me nihil in votis habere magis quam accepta beneficia debito ἀντευεργεσίαϛ modo agnoscere. Tu pro data occasione experire, et vale. Dabam Basileae pridie Nonas Februarias MDCXXXVI Reverentiae Tuae devotissimus, etc.

Title: Letter to Michael Castell 3 June 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 228 Microfilm pdf p. 360-361 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini Johann Jacob Frey to Michael Castell Date: 1636-06-03 Place: Basel
Text:
Sir,
you oblige me too much by honouring me with your remembrance having received three of your lettres in the last two weeks? [...] accompanied by letters from Mr. William Beecher and from my cousin Battier, dated from London on the 15 and 20 april and also of 13 May last, all full of courtesy, which I will not fail to recognize in my turn if God gives me the possibility.
For the rest, your advice goes well with [...] already on the way to Ireland [...]
Line reference: @100028 Letter to Michael Castell 3 June 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007040 Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford / NaHu#007020 William Beecher / NaHu#007083 Jacob Battier
URL:
Monsieur,
vous m'obligez par trop, en me faisant l'honuer de vos souvenirs: ayant deçu trois de vos lettres depuis quinze jours de çà?? Accompagnées des lettres de Seigneur William Beecher et de mon cousin Battier, leurs dates ? de Londres du 15 et 20 Avril ?? aussi du 13 Mai passée. Toutes pleines de courtoisie laquelle si jamais Dieu me donne le pouvoir je ne manquerai point de reconnaître de son lieu. Au reste, vos conseils s'accordent bien à ?? qui sont d'autre déjà en chemin pour l'Irlande mais de l'état où je suis içi je ne peux sans avoir au préalable? Des lettres de Monseigneur le Viceroy à cette République, ur obtenir congé honorablw de de loieu; et oour m'assurer qu'instant arrivé là, je ne manquerai point d'être m'installer de ma place. Les pacquets qui vous ont été adressez [sic] au mois de janvier

Title: Letter to James Ussher 13 June 1636
Bibliographical reference: UB BASEL Frey-Gryn I 23, fol. 4 Microfilm pdf p. 8 Transcription and annotation Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling and punctuation normalized Johann Jacob Frey to James Ussher, draft Date: 1636-06-13 Place: Basel
Text:
Most reverend Father in God,
The daily hope of a letter from my Lord Deputy and one from your grace to the University, made me ? continue ? with a resolution to begin my journey immediately after the receiving of these things I could not settle my affairs here as I looked for. But for want of these being still tied to this place as will in regard of my charge here, as in respect of my condition being now a married man; I must crave your Grace's pardon for beseeching any humble favour ? again, ? you would be pleased to move my Lord Deputy to ? his donation by a warrant for my absence, and and ? demand m of this senate in a public wager ??? would likewise this university with a letter ??? to gain my freedom for coming away with their good will. The bearer of this into England is a Master of Arts of this town his name Mr Schönauer very well skilled in ? tongues and intending to pass some time at Oxford or Cambridge. He hath heard me speak for much of your Grace and I believe he will seek for an opportunity to kiss your Grace's hands which I beseech your Grace may be with his good liking and leave (?). He was heretofore one of Buxtorfius' scholars and can tell your Grace something of the state of learning in France, bring to pass this way and to stay a while in Paris. Which bids me end this letter without any relation of news not knowing how soon it may come into Ireland; only your Grace is to receive the manuscripts of the Waldhuser
Comment: A poignant document: two months before his death, Frey is looking forward to taking up the post of Dean of Armagh. The letter may not have been sent.
Line reference: @100037 Letter to James Ussher 13 June 1636
Modifications: NaHu#007040 Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford / NaHu#007908 Martin Schönauer

Title: Letter to Thomas Wentworth 15 November 1636
Bibliographical reference: Laud, William. "Letter to Thomas Wentworth 15 November 1636." Workes VII 296.
Text: I received a letter, before your Lordship's last being with me at Croydon, from the Earl of Leicester. The main business in it was for his Secretary [Jacob Battier] to be Dean of Armagh. The man himself brought me the letter. He told me he was a Deacon, and that my Lord of Lincoln ordained him. But I saw nothing in him or about him like a man in Orders. Young he was, and in long hair, his clothes all in the fashion, and to my eye most unfit every way to be a prime Dean in that kingdom. My answer was accordingly, that his Lordship might expect kindness from me, but it must be such as I might perform with my own honour. But I had spoken and written so much to your Lordship against putting young men into eminent places in the Church, that I could not now forget it, at all times after that I was with you.

Title: Letter to Robert Sidney 21 June 1637
Bibliographical reference: Scan from the internet Large 4to. 1 p. on bifolium with integral address panel ("A Monseigneur Monseigneur Conte de Lester a Paris"). On watermarked paper. Tears where opened repaired; left margin laid down on modern paper for an album. Folds, slightly browned. Artikel-Nr.: 52818. Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized Sir Kenelm Digby to Robert Sidney, Earl of Leicester Date: 1637-06-21
Text:
My good Lord,
Mr. Battier's dispatch hath been so uncertain, as I prepared not for it till I should understand of a certain time pitched for his departure; and the knowledge of that came not to me until this very instant that he is going, which maketh it too late for me to trouble your honour with any longer a letter than to congratulate with you the happy conclusion of the treaty you have carried and effected with so much honor. I hope about 3 weeks hence to wait upon your honour in Paris. In the meantime I humbly kiss your hands and rest
your honour’s most humble servant,
Kenelm Digby.
London, 21 June 1637
Comment:
Digby travelled on the continent,
Referring to the hasty return to Paris of the recipient's secretary James Battier, sending (premature) congratulations on a putative Anglo-French treaty, and hoping himself to visit Leicester in Paris in about three weeks' time.
In April 1636 Charles I had sent Leicester as Ambassador Extraordinary to Louis XIII of France, seconding the mission of the Ambassador in Ordinary, Viscount Scudamore, whose negotiations with the French had proved unsuccessful. Despite working hard for a projected Anglo-French agreement, other factors (such as intrigues against Cardinal Richelieu and secret talks with the exiled Marie de Medici) doomed the treaty from the start. - Kenelm Digby, the elder son of Sir Everard Digby (1578-1606), executed for his part in the Gunpowder Plot, was a man of many parts, including those of a courtier (he was a friend of Charles I and was known to Cromwell), poet, pirate, alchemist, book collector, and inventor. He travelled extensively, fighting Venetian galleys off Iskenderun and living successively in France and Italy. "In 1657 his increasingly poor health led Digby to take the waters at Montpellier, where he gave his famous account of the 'powder of sympathy', which cured wounds by being rubbed on the weapon that inflicted them. It was a strong solution of vitriol (copper sulfate) in rainwater, which could be improved by drying in the sun and by mixture with gum tragacanth" (DSB IV, 95).
Line reference: @100054 Letter to Robert Sidney 21 June 1637
Overlap/Similarity: Robert Sidney, second Earl of Leicester

Title: Letter to James Ussher 18 August 1638
Bibliographical reference: QUOTED FROM Parr, Richard. The life of the Most Reverend Father in God, James Usher, late Lord Arch-Bishop of Armagh, primate and metropolitan of all Ireland with a Collection of three hundred letters between the said Lord Primate and most of the eminentest persons for piety and learning in his time ... / collected and published from original copies under their own hands, by Richard Parr. London: Nathanael Ranew, 1686. Zzz "LETTER CXCVI. A Letter from Mr. Battiere, to the most Reverend James Usher Arch-bishop of Armagh." Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized. Jacob Battier to James Ussher Date: 1637-08-18
Text:
Most Reverend Father in God, my most honoured Lord; I Have received a Letter from your Grace by Mr. Cullen, with much joy, as well to hear of your Grace's good Health (which I pray to God may continue long so for the Good of Christendom) as to see me favoured with some Employment again for your Grace, than whom I know no body living I desire to serve with more affection: I will with one word, set down here what hath been done in your Lordship's Business since Mr. Cullen's arrival. I brought him first to my Lord the Earl of Leicester, who for your Grace's sake, and his own worth, shewed him all kindness, and to Mr. Jones. I carried him to Mr. Duluy, where he made acquaintance, bestowing a Complement upon them from your Grace. Pere Sirmond and Mr. Rigault, we could not find at home yet, nor Gabriel the Sionita, whose great Bible I shewed him also, and conferred the Syrian Characters together, of which [Page 489] there be three or four here; but of this Mr. Cullen will give a better account a while hence; for I have written also to Geneva, where such a Character is to be sold, to have the sight of it in print, and at what rate they mean to sell it, to compare the Prices and Characters together with these here. In the mean while Mr. Cullen is advised to sequester himself from English and Irish, to profit the more in the French Tongue, for conversing afterwards with those that he hath business withal, and to that end I hope he will not be denied a prorogation of his licence of travelling and absenting himself from the college for some few months longer, with the continuation of his Stipend (he being employed in Work so good for the Common Wealth) especially upon your Grace's Commendation. I have set one to work for the transcribing of Concil. Lemovicense, and Theodori Poenitentiale, and will go on with the rest one by one, as I can get them; for to demand so much at once, would seem strange to them, although they be very courteous and officious. Of printed Books, I bought Vita Leonis and Caroli of Sirmondus; but the rest marked to me, are not his. Hincmari Opusc. are of Cordesius, and I think you Grace hath them. Ivo Carnotensis of Juret. Damianus of Caetan a Benedictine. Bellarm. de Script. Eccl. of Sirmond, but scarce anything altered in it. Browerus de Treverensis Ecclesiae Antiquit, I cannot get yet. There is nothing added to the Councils of Binius, nor any thing printed of St. Chrysostom but what your Grace hath. Du Chesnes's third and fourth Volume are a-printing, but not yet finished.
This Kingdom being now in Wars on all sides, doth not afford any great Design for the advancement of Learning. Of late, one Mr. Gallant a Counsellor of State, and a Protestant, set forth a Book de Franco allodio in French, in which he gives a touch unto the Waldenses History, and Simon de Montfort: I wrote of this Man heretofore to your Grace, as one best versed in that History, and best stored with their Writings; this Book I will send with the rest.
I wonder your Grace hath not received my former, with one from Mr. Buxtorf; if I am not deceived, I sent them away with those of the City and University of Basel to my Lord Deputy; to whom I made bold to add one of mine, to thank his Greatness for the Favour of my Naturalization in Ireland, and for his nobleness to my Kinsman Frey. I am not so out with Ireland, (where I have heretofore received so good entertainment) but I hope to see it again; which I desire the more for your Grace's sake, to tender my best Respects in Person to so much worth; and should think me happy if I could deserve a mean Prebend in your Cathedral, to wait more close upon your Grace. I humbly crave your Grace's Blessing, and remain with my hearty Prayers for your Health and Prosperity, Your Grace's most humbly obedient and devoted Servant, J[ames] Battier. Paris zzz August 1637. [Postscript starts here]

Title: Letter to Theodor Haack 24 November 1639
Bibliographical reference: Copy Letter, Mersenne To [Theodore Haack], In French Dating: 24 November 1639 Ref: 18/2/3A-B Notes: See Correspondance du P. Marin Mersenne vol. VIII, pp. 636-40 for date, names, etc. https://www.dhi.ac.uk/hartlib/view?docset=main&docname=18A_02_03&term0=transtext_frey#highlight [18/2/3A] [left margin, Hartlib's hand?: No. 2.] [normalized spelling].
Text:
normalization tbe

Monsieur
Encore que j'ai eu trop peu de Temps pour faire response à la vôtre, neanmoins je vous dirai quelquechose; reservant le reste pour le premier voyage; je vous dirai donc premièrement, que tout ce que je pourrai pour Monsieur Pell, je le ferai très librement, tant parce qu'il est de vos Amis, que parce qu'il le mérite, puis qu'il est porté pour le bien public. Je serai bien aisé de savoir son Sentiment sur le livre de Monsieur Descartes. Le pauvre Monsieur Elicman promettait beaucoup, s'il eût vécu davantage. Pour ce qui est de Monsieur Plattes, son Trésor d'Observations me fait beaucoup espérer de lui, et vous m'obligerez de lui baiser les mains de ma part: il y a un autre Français nommé Palissy, qui a semblablement observé beaucoup de choses, des Eaux, des Mineraux, de la marne pour fumer la Terre etc; s'il ne l'a veu, il y aura moyen de le lui envoyer, s'il [le] désire; Encouragez le de nous donner sa Maîtresse de l'art. Quant aux Observations de l'aimant, l'on n'en a ici tiré que 50 copies, pour envoyer à Rome, suivant le désir de Monsieur Naudé, qui m'a prié de les lui faire imprimer, lequel demeure chez le Cardinal Bagne à Rome; Si j'eusse creu, qu'elles eussent deu parvenir entre les mains des sçavants chez vous, je les eusse polies et amplifiees davantage. Vous me parlez de l'aymant d'un Ministre de vostre Cognoissance qui tire 21lb ne pesant que 3lb. Ie crois, que vous entendez, qu'il est armé, quoy que vous ne le disiez pas, je vous prie de le sçavoir, s'il faire se peut, combien il tire pesant, lors qu'il est desarmé; Et s'il est excellent, nous aviserons à d'autres choses. Vous ne pouviez pas mieux vous addresser, qu'à moy pour sçavoir, ce qui est de ce que Campanelle, ou le Gazetier sous son Nom a produit de la bonté des Lunettes, et de L'apparence de Mars et de Saturne: Car outre que j'en ay fait l'Essay avec des Lunettes de Fontana, qui venoient de Florence et avoit 7. pieds et demy de long, qui ne faisoient rien qui vaille, pour une si grande longeur, Ie vous asseure, que Campanelle n'y a jamais rien sceu ny veu, n'estant fondè que sur un memoire de Naples, envoyé de la part de l'Artisan Fontana, De la [?] vient, qu'il s'est rendu ridicule icy à tous les Sçavants. Ce n'est peut estre pas, qu'en Italie le Fontana, n'ait fait quelque bonne Lunette, laquelle à peu pres fait parestre Mars et Saturne suivant le Memoire, mais rien n'en a paru suffisament[altered], ni à Campanelle, ni en France Mais un Gentilhomme de mes amis à commencè à faire des lunettes spheriques, qui n'ayant que 3. pieds de long, font paroistre Venus aussi grande, que la Lune paroist à la veue ordinaire; Et il va travailler aux lunettes hyperboliques, et Ellyptiques de Monsieur des Cartes, dont il viendra à bout, ou il sera impossible. Je vous [ferai?] savoir, ce qui en réussira. Pour Monsieur Frey il y a bien 10 ans, qu'il est mort, ou environ, et n'a rien fait de consequence que ce que vous dites. [...] Nous avons icy des personnes qui observent au ciel, et qui y remarquent beaucoup de choses, et entr'autres Monsieur Gassend[?] et nostre Monsieur Morin Professeur Royal, travaille puissament à son Astrologie Gallicane; Voyla Monsieur, ce que j'ay peu vous respondre pour le present, comme le mesme 24 de Nov. auquel j'ay receu la Vostre, Ie vous prie de continuer à me faire sçavoir, ce qu'il y aura de rare et d'excellent en matiere de Livres et d'Esprits et d'Inventions, dans l'Angleterre ou Escosse, et mutuellement je vous escriray, ce qui sera icy ou ailleurs, lors que je sçauray que cela sera digne de vostre Entretien. Ie suis tousiours cependant Vostre [Treshumble?] Serviteur F. M. Mersenne M.
Comment: The reference may be to Johann Jacob Frey, who had however died just three rather than ten years earlier.
Line reference: @100266 Letter to Theodor Haack 24 November 1639

Title: Letter to the Earl of Cork December 1640
Bibliographical reference: Marcombes, Isaac.  Letter to the Earl of Cork December 1640.
Text: [Summary from the Chatsworth Archive] Both his pupils have now written to his lordship. Assures him they make very good use of their time. On 1 March, they will leave Geneva for Florecne, there to continue their mathematics, to study the art of Architecture, and the use of the Italian tongue. At Florence they must keep a coach and live gallantly, for it is a court where English gentlemen are much observed. Begs him to get leave from the King that they go to Rome, a thing forbidden by the laws of England; also to procure Latin letters commendatory to foreign Courts. Proposed route. Remittances.

Authors: Robert Sidney, second Earl of Leicester
Title: Letter to Algernon Percy 9 September 1634
Bibliographical reference: https://www.british-history.ac.uk/rushworth-papers/vol5/pp1-25 Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini Robert Sidney, Earl of Leicester to Algernon Percy, Earl of Northumberland Date: 1642-09-09 Place: Nottingham
Text:
My Lord,
though I have written thrice to the Commissioners for the Affairs of Ireland since my coming from London, to give them Account of my stay at Court, and that I have also written several Letters to some particular Friends, in hope that thereby the Truth might be known and myself rightly understood; yet because those Letters peradventure may have miscarried, and left I should incur the censure of the Parliament for Negligence or Slackness in that Service to which I have been designed, I will truly and as briefly as I can relate to your Lordship how I have behaved myself; and if your Lordship please you may communicate it to the House of Peers; as in your Judgment and Favour to me you shall think fit; and I hope it will appear that as I have been very impatient of this delay, so I have not wanted diligence in the Solicitation of my Dispatch. When I came to York, I told the King that I was come thither to receive his Majesty's Commandments and Instructions for that Employment which he had done me the Honour to confer upon me, and I did humbly beseech him that I might not be staid at Court, because the Parliament did desire my speedy repair into Ireland, and that his Service, as I conceived, did require it; at least that some [page 342] Governor, if I were not worthy of that Charge, should be presently sent into that Kingdom. The King told me that he would think of it. But I must confess I did not find his Majesty so ready to dispatch me as I hoped and expected. From that time I did not fail to beseech his Majesty to send me away, upon every opportunity that I had of speaking to him; and I think there passed not a Day that I did not desire the Secretaries of State and some other Persons about the King, to put his Majesty in mind of me and to hasten my Dismission. Divers times I made it my Petition to the King that he would dispatch me, or declare his Intention that he would not let me go at all. The King said, My Instructions should be drawn, and that he would give order to Mr. Secretary Nicholas to do it as speedily as he could: In expectation whereof I staid about three Weeks till the King came from York, at which time his Majesty appointed me to follow him to Nottingham, promising that there I should have my Expeditions. I obeyed his Majesty and came after him to this Town, where I have attended ever since, perpetually soliciting to be dispatched, and beseeching his Majesty that I might either go to my Employment, or have his leave to retire myself to my own House and private Condition: That if he were unwilling to trust me in an Employment of so great Importance, I did beseech him that I might be no Burden to his Thoughts; and that he would be pleased to let me know his Resolution; because I conceived myself to be under a heavy Censure both of the Parliament and of the whole Kingdom, whilst possibly they might think it my Fault that I was so long absent from that Charge which I had undertaken. 'Tis to no purpose to tell you every Passage; but this I protest to your Lordship, That [page 343] if it had been to save the Lives of all my Friends and of myself, I could not have done more to procure my Dispatch. Nevertheless I have not been able to advance it one Step; nor have I seen anything to make me hope to have it quickly, till this Morning Mr. Secretary Nicholas gave me a Draught of my Instructions to peruse. So I hope that between this and Monday I shall have done that part, and I will do the best I can to procure some other thing, without which I know not how I shall be able to do any acceptable Service in that Kingdom. Your Lordship knows I am a Servant, and I could not run away if I would, or at least it had been to little purpose, though I should have adventured to do so indecent and so undutiful an Action. Therefore I hope it will be believed that I have not been to blame. Now with your Lordship's leave I shall trouble you with another Particular, wherein perhaps I suffer in the Opinion of those who know not what has passed, though I be as innocent as a newborn Child; nay, I have opposed it as much as I had Power to do. The King being informed at York by some officious Persons, that certain Draught-Horses were provided to be sent into Ireland, his Majesty told me that he must needs have them for his own use. I did humbly beseech him not to take them away from his own Service in Ireland, for which they were bought, and in which they were to be employed; and besides what I said myself, I used means by others to save the Horses, so that I heard no more of it till I came hither; but then his Majesty told me again, That he must needs have those Horses, and pressed me to send for them. I represented to his Majesty the inconsiderableness of those few Horses, and that the Parliament might take it very ill, in regard that the Horses were bought with their Money for the Service of the poor [page 344) Kingdom of Ireland: Therefore I did beseech him not to take them; or howsoever, that he would secure me from being an Instrument in that which I conceived would much hurt his Affairs; and that I being trusted by the Parliament, could neither do it myself, nor consent that any other should do that which was a Breach of Trust, and a great Disservice even to his Majesty himself. Notwithstanding this the King sent to me by Mr. Endymion Porter and Sir George Hay at several times to the same purpose, but I returned the same Answer; adding this also, That I could not do it and be an 〈◊◊〉 his Service, though it be true thus the King said he would restore the Horses or pay for them. But for all this it pleased his Majesty to employ one Errington who served me, and gave him a Warrant to fetch the Horses. Errington told me of it; and I forbad him as far as I could, to do it, telling him that if he did, he must not look to have anything to do with me forever; and that I made no doubt the Parliament would hang him for stealing their Horses. This and more I said to Errington in the presence of James Battier my Secretary, who will witness it: And conceiving it to be an unjust thing in itself, displeasing to the Parliament, and hurtful to the King's Service, I protested against it; though Errington said, that his Majesty had commanded him upon his Allegiance to execute the Warrant. But indeed I told him that I did not believe him; nor could think that his Majesty would command a Subject upon his Allegiance to take away other Men’s Horses. This I thought sufficient; but it seems I was deceived; for Errington without my consent or knowledge went from Nottingham towards Chester as I heard afterwards, and I have never seen him since nor heard from him. What he hath done I know not, but I sent to [page 345] Chester that the Horses should be presently shipped away, and I caused my Secretary to write to Master Hawkin to take care that neither Errington nor any Body from him should receive any more Money of Mr. Loftus or his Deputy, to provide the rest of the Horses; for as yet I think there has been only Sixteen hundred Pounds issued to buy two hundred of the six hundred Horses allowed by the Parliament; and of that Sixteen hundred Pounds I will do the best I can to get a good Account, whereof the Parliament, God willing, shall be informed with my utmost Care and Diligence. Truly, my Lord, I do the best I can to serve my Country: They that are wiser may do more; but of anything contrary to the Duty of an honest Man, the Parliament upon strict examination shall never find me guilty. For the reputation of Honesty and Fidelity is, and I can say no more, as dear to me as your esteeming me
Your Lordship's humble and affectionate Servant,
R[obert] Leicester. Nottingham, Sept. 1642.
Line reference: @100052 Letter to Algernon Percy 9 September 1634

Title: Letter to Johannes Buxtorf the Younger February 1653
Bibliographical reference: Quoted from Parr? Transcription, spelling normalized James Ussher to Johannes Buxtorf Date: 1653 Place: London
Text: I received, most egregious sir, your letter of the 6th of November. [...] when our Frey was still among the living.
Comment: ADDRESS Clarissimo Viro D. Johanni Buxtorfio, S. Theologiae Doctori, et Linguae Hebraeae Professori. Basileae.
Line reference: @100055 Letter to Johannes Buxtorf the Younger February 1653
URL:
Accepi (Vir Clarissime) Literas tuas datas 6o Novemb. Gratissima sanè omnis à Te ad nos venit Epistola; haec verò eo nomine gratior, quia rationem aliquam scriptorum tuorum, & nuper editorum, & mox brevi edendorum communicat. Dissertationem tuam de Sponsalibus & Divortiis, superioribus Nundinis Vernalibus publicatam, nondum mihi videre contigit; cupio autem, quamprimùm id commodè fieri possit, oculis usurpare; Nam cum abundè nobis in caeteris tuis operibus & Diatribis satisfeceris, non dubito, quin eandem, quam ex aliis voluptatem cepimus, ex isthoc quo{que} scripto capiamus. Et voti me mox fore compotem Bibliopolae pollicentur, quod significo Tibi, nè molestiâ mihi transmittendi, quod intendis, exemplar, onerares. Miratus sum ubi tam diù haeserit exemplar Epistolae nostrae de Textûs Hebraici Veteris Testamenti variantibus lectionibus ad Capellum scriptae; Curavi enim inter alia exemplaria ad Bootium nostrum missa (qui etiamnum Parisiis degit) ut unum ad Te, quâ fieri posset festinatione, mitteretur. Sed, ex quo tuas accepimus, aliae nobis à D. Bootio literae missae sunt, quibus promittit Te non diù (quantum per ipsum steterit) Epistolâ illâ nostrâ cariturum. Theatrum sapientiae caelestis nuper à D. Theodoro Zuingero publicatum spero eadem nave unà cum Dissertatione tua intrà hos paucos dies ad nos iri delatum. Peramicè facit, quod unum ex scriptis nostris Anglicanis, opera Pastoris Gallici jam Latinè loquentibus, lucubrationibus suis inseruerit. Salutem, quaeso Te, meis verbis illi impertias, ut pote homini non solum hac gratia primum mihi noto, sed olim per commercium literarum, dum Freius noster in vivis versaretur, familiari. Anticriticam tuam secundo Numine ad coronidem tandem perducas. Quicquid ex ingenio tuo prodierit, non dubito quin fuerit [in non-Latin alphabet]. Methodum operis quam indigitasti, probo; Etiamsi solus, aut in paucis es, qui argumentum hoc faeliciter [page 587] tractare noverint, vereor ut Capellum ab admitatione [in non-Latin alphabet] ō dimovens; quorum tamen (quae dicitur) translationem tam ab eo abesse in Epistola mea scribo, ut cum Hebraei Codicis autoritate certet, ut asseram potius nullius esse Interpretum eorum, quicun{que} illi fuerint, autoritatem, qui pro libitu suo, addere, detrahere, mutare, quod volupe est facere, insuper habent. Vale, Vir Doctissime; & tam corporis validi, quàm ingenli vegeti (quorum infirmitate, praesertim inter scribendum, Te nuper laborasse doleo) beneficio fruere, ad illius gloriam, qui utrumque nobis solus indulget, & publicum Ecclesiae Emolumentum. Ja. Armachanus.
Londini 1653.

Title: On the Late Massacre in Piedmont
Bibliographical reference: Milton, John. "On the Late Massacre in Piedmont." Poems. Everyman's Library. London: Dent, 1976. 83.
Text:
Avenge, O Lord, thy slaughtered saints, whose bones
Lie scattered on the Alpine mountains cold,
Even them who kept thy truth so pure of old,
When all our fathers worshiped stocks and stones;
Forget not: in thy book record their groans
Who were thy sheep and in their ancient fold
Slain by the bloody Piedmontese that rolled
Mother with infant down the rocks. Their moans
The vales redoubled to the hills, and they
To Heaven. Their martyred blood and ashes sow
O'er all th' Italian fields where still doth sway
The triple tyrant; that from these may grow
A hundredfold, who having learnt thy way
Early may fly the Babylonian woe.
Comment: Milton is referring to the massacre of Protestant Valdenses in 1655. SECONDARY Greteman, Blaine. "Milton and the Early Modern Social Network." Milton Quarterly 49.2 (May 2015): 79-95.

Title: Letter to Johann Jacob Hofmann 25 September 1667
Bibliographical reference: Buxtorf, Johannes. Letter to Johann Jacob Hofmann 25 September 1667. Cambridge. Basel, UB, UBH G2 I 19b:65-66 Brief an [Johann] Jakob Hofmann / von Johannes Buxtorf Cambridge, 25. Sept. 1667 2 Bl.; 15 cm Transcription Regula Hohl Trillini, spelling normalized
Text:
Cambridge, September 25th, 1664
I doubt not but you will heartily laugh at the first looking upon this present and think it either madness or presumption in me to writ[e] in this language but I must tell you that it is either but a mere imitation rather of others for I remember when time was that I had your more familiar conversation, I saw several letters written to you even of our own countrymen in Italian, Dutch, French (yea some are grown to so high a love to this latter language that were even German letters they must begin with a French Monsieur and end with a très humble serviteur if they will not pass for cobblers) so that if you should give any severer censure upon this, you would condemn a great many of your friends or else put me in a lower rank among them and even this same language we do not much dislike for several times we very willingly and thankfully accept of our ministers an English greeting instead of the Angelical. But there are two things chiefly, which I hope will sufficiently plead my cause, your particular good inclination to this language (which I may gather out of the desire to those books I bought for you) and your kindness and love towards me, of which as I had ever since proofs enough, so will I not hope that now I shall have lost it, for a little time’s silence for which I should begin to plead indulgence if I did not think it […] tedious for you to read a letter stuffed up with nothing else but compliments and supervacuous words. I know you look for other things; of which I would very willingly acquaint you in these barren times and place would furnish me with any worth of your reading. For since the peace lately proclaimed the old questions What News! Is almost come out of fashion. ‘Tis like the next parliament will produce something, as it is already talked of a Comprehensive Act to come out for the settlement of Protestantism in its due latitude. For which (some think) a foundation is already laid in the late changes at Court (if it is to be feared) it will hardly be done without some troubles. For the affection of the predominant party to the other, shows enough that they will never suffer any advantage for to be granted to them by their consent. What the French envoyés ? is not known yet; I can hardly believe that it is one ? for complimenting and congratulating his Majesty as he pretends but rather (as some will discourse) for to invite this Kind to assist his Master against the Spanish Netherlands upon condition that whatever He shall take ? as in the late war between the two crowns Oliver did. I bought for you Ross' Muses' Interpreter, , Godwin's Antiquities but with an English and Dutch dictionariy I could never meet although I did my best endeavour. There is one in fol[ío] of 9 languages which hath the Dutch but methinks it is very imperfect, and the price is very high, i.e. 15 English shillings. If you desire to have it you may send me word betimes and I shall do my best as also any other thing that layeth in my power. The two former I would had [sic] sent you ere this, had I met with a friend whom I durst have troubled with. Books are grown so dear since that dismal accident of the fair [?] that a man may scarce buy any except he knows not to employ his money otherwise. Those few I bought for myself I shall send over about next spring, by which time I shall possible [sic] be myself at some where I shall have the happiness to see you and all my friends in good health. They are a-printing in London all Selden's Latin works in two volumes in fol[io]. If you had ever occasion to look upon Mr. Mieg's English books, pray will you do me the favour as to send me a Catalogue of them and give me notice notice [sic] whether you desire any of them. Pray good Sir let me have now and then some lines of you (if you can spare so much time) till that happy time that we may mutuas audire et reddere voces [Latin: hear each other's voices and reply]. I am forced to make haste lest the post should be gone. With my best respects to you, Dr. Zwinger and a tender of my respect for your brother I rest out of my study in Emmanuel College
your very affectionate friend and humble servant Johannes Buxtorf
Comment: ADDRESS: to Monsieur Jacques Hoffmann
Line reference: @100118 Letter to Johann Jacob Hoffmann 25 September 1667

Title: The Travels of Francis Tallents, 1671-1673
Bibliographical reference: Tallents, Francis. The Travels of Francis Tallents, 1671-1673. Introduced and annotated, with bibliographical notes and index, by Janice V. Cox.
Text: The Travels of Francis Tallents, 1671-1673
Comment:
In February 1671 Tallents, a Dissenting minister of Huguenot ancestry, set off on a tour of continental Europe as tutor to the sons of the English Presbyterians and MPs Hugh Boscawen and Richard Hampden. During the next two and a half years he and his companions travelled huge distances on horseback over much of France and Switzerland, making protracted stays in a number of cities and a brief excursion into northern Italy.
The Journal which Francis Tallents kept at that time is
full of wonderful details of the people they met, the places
they saw, and the events that they witnessed, although, sadly,
one of the young men, Theophilus Boscawen, died of smallpox
in Strasbourg as they were about to leave for Paris on the last leg of their journey. After Boscawen’s death, Tallents and Hampden stayed in Paris for seven months and were much impressed by the improvements being made by Louis XIV, and by the magnificence of his buildings and the opulence of his court. Tallents’s account of his travels, published here for the first time, offers valuable insights into many aspects of France at that period. He takes a particular interest in the liturgy and practices of the Roman Catholic and Reformed churches and of the Catholic orders, a central concern throughout being the life and situation of the Huguenot communities.

Title: Lettres sur les Anglais et les Français
Bibliographical reference: von Muralt, Beat Ludwig. Lettres sur les Anglais et les Français. 1725.
Text:
Lettres sur les Anglais et les Français
Travelled 1694-1695
Comment: 1681 immatrikulierte er sich in Universität Genf, um dort Jura und Theologie zu studieren. 1690 als Hauptmann bei der Schweizergarde in Versailles in französische Dienste. 1694 machte er eine Reise mit seinem Bruder Franz Ludwig (1669–1753) über Holland nach England (vermutlich vornehmlich London) und kehrte 1695 über Frankreich zurück. 1699 heiratete er und ließ sich auf einem Landgut nieder. 1701 geriet er in Bern als Pietist und früher Aufklärer in Konflikt mit der Kirche und wurde aus Bern verbannt. Auch in Genf konnte er nicht bleiben und so ging er 1702 nach Colombier im preußischen Neuenburg, wo auf dem Gut seiner Frau seine Studien fortsetzen konnte.
